(6)  For the purpose of begging or soliciting alms, provided that this section shall not apply to persons soliciting alms for bona fide religious, charitable or eleemosynary organizations with the authorization of such organizations; or 
(7)  For the purpose of selling, purchasing, trading or otherwise exchanging, procuring or making available illegal drugs or contraband. 
(Code 2000, § 10-411) 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal arrest, fine and imprisonment of vagrants, 11 O.S. § 22-123. 
Sec. 36-222. - Sleeping in public. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and sunrise, to sleep on any street, in any other public place, or on any property of another without the express or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge of such place. 
(b)  It is unlawful for a person to be on or about the premises of any public or private school or other public building, or in or about a depot of a public carrier. 
(Code 2000, § 10-413) 
State Law reference- Authority for municipal arrest, fine and imprisonment of vagrants, 11 O.S. § 22-123. 
Sec. 36-223. - Begging prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to beg alms for any person, organization or agency except an organization or agency, public or private, whose purpose or one of whose purposes is to aid persons in need. 
(Code 2000, § 10-414) 
Sec. 36-224. - Malicious mischief. 
    It is an offense for any person to commit any act of malicious mischief. Malicious mischief as used in this section shall include the doing of any act which shall deprive any person of the exercise of any lawful right. It shall include the failure or refusal to perform a duty when it is the duty of such person to perform and which the failure or refusal results in the deprivation of a person's enjoyment of some lawful right of person or property. It shall include any act which shall exclude any person from the full enjoyment of any and all lawful rights without any impairment, abridgement, injury or damage arising out of the act of the party accused. 
(Code 2000, § 10-219) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief generally, 21 O.S. § 1751 et seq. 
Sec. 36-225. - Removal or defacing flags. 
    It is unlawful and an offense for any person to remove, destroy, molest, deface or disarrange any flag or other decoration that may be used by other persons in, upon or about any building within the city to indicate the celebration of any holiday or public event without the consent of the owner thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 10-217) 
State Law reference- Mutilation, treating with indignity or destroying flag, 21 O.S. § 371. 
Sec. 36-226. - Loud noise or music prohibited; amplified sound. 
    It is unlawful for any person to disturb the peace and quietude of any part of the city by operating, having operated, or permitting to be operated any contrivance, whether electric or not, any motor vehicle, or any other device, with or without a loudspeaker, in such a manner as to emit loud music, noise or words. However, this section shall not prohibit religious bodies from playing chimes, bells, carillons or other religious music. 
(Code 2000, § 10-308) 
State Law reference- Disturbance by loud or unusual noise unlawful, 21 O.S. § 1362. 
Secs. 36-227-36-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-246. - Injuring automobiles and other vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person to start, otherwise meddle with, molest, enter or occupy, any automobile or other vehicle belonging to another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 10-202) 
State Law reference- Loitering in, injuring or molesting automobile or motor vehicles, 21 O.S. § 1787. 
Sec. 36-247. - Destroying or injuring buildings and other property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to destroy, injure, deface, besmear, or molest any structure, building, outbuilding, fence, or any other property, real or personal, public or private, belonging to another; or to use any such property wrongfully to the detriment of the owner or other person entitled to its use; or to interfere wrongfully with the use of any such property by its owner or any other person entitled to its use. 
(Code 2000, § 10-203) 
Sec. 36-248. - Throwing or shooting at persons or property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw or shoot any stone, shot or other object into or across any street or alley, or in any place where he is likely to hit another person wrongfully or to injure property, or to throw or shoot any stone, shot or other object at any person, vehicle, structure, electric light or other property of another (whether public or private), except in case where such is done in defense of oneself, of another person or of property. 
(Code 2000, § 10-205) 
State Law reference- Discharging firearm and throwing missiles in public place prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1364. 
Sec. 36-249. - Placing signs on property of another. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, stick, tack, paste, post, paint, mark, write or print any sign, poster, picture, announcement, advertisement, bill placard, device or inscription upon any public or private building, fence, sidewalk, bridge, viaduct, post, automobile, other vehicle or other property of another, without the consent of the owner or person in charge thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 10-204) 
Sec. 36-250. - Throwing advertising on street, prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to throw, leave or deposit, or cause to be thrown, left or deposited, upon any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public area, any handbill, circular, or other advertising matter. 
(Code 2000, § 10-209) 
State Law reference- Throwing, leaving, or depositing trash near roadway, 21 O.S. § 1205. 
Sec. 36-251. - Throwing injurious substances. 
    It is unlawful for any person to purposely or premeditatedly put or throw upon the person or property of another, or upon any animal, any acid, corrosive or other irritating or harmful substance, or human or animal waste or urine, with intent to injure or harass the person, property or animal. 
(Code 2000, § 10-210) 
State Law reference- Discharging firearm and throwing missiles in public place prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1364. 
Secs. 36-252-36-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PUBLIC PROPERTY 

Sec. 36-281. - Defacing public streets and trees. 
    It is unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Willfully or wantonly cut, deface or in any way injure any tree or sapling standing or growing in any of the streets, alleys or public places within the city; 
(2)  Attach any guy wires, telephone, telegraph, or electric wire, or any wire to any live tree; 
(3)  Dig any hole, ditch or trench in any public street, road, avenue or alley, or any other public premises or ground within, belonging to or under the supervision or control of the city; 
(4)  Take or remove any dirt, earth or any substance from any street, road, alley or other public place in the city; or to cut, break or otherwise injure any pavement, curb or gutter therein; or 
(5)  Connect any driveway to any street or other public place without first securing permission from the city inspector so to do. 
Any such digging, removing, or driveway connection shall be done under the supervision of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 10-212) 
Sec. 36-282. - Tampering with or damaging public utilities. 
    It is unlawful for any person to connect or attach any kind of pipe, wire or other contrivance to any pipe, line, wire or other conductor carrying gas, water or electricity and belonging to a public utility (whether publicly or privately owned), in such a manner as to enable him to consume or use the gas, water or electricity without it passing through the meter or any other way so as to evade payment therefor. It is also unlawful for any person to damage, molest, tamper with, or destroy any pipe, line, wire, meter, or other part of any public utility, including any telegraph or telephone system. 
(Code 2000, § 10-206) 
State Law reference- Willfully and knowingly injuring or destroying pipeline transportation system, 17 O.S. § 6.1. 
Sec. 36-283. - Tampering with utilities prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, corporation or association. 
    Utility means any person, firm, corporation, district or association, whether private, municipal, body politic or cooperative, which is engaged in the sale, generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water or gas. 
    Utility service means the furnishing, sale, generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water or gas by a utility as defined herein. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person, with intent to defraud a utility, to: 
(1)  Alter, tamper with, injure or knowingly allow the altering, tampering with or injuring of any pipeline, line, wire, conduit, conductor, meter, meter seal, transformer or other equipment used by a utility to deliver or register service; 
(2)  Prevent any installed metering device from registering correctly the quantity of service passing through such metering device; 
(3)  Make or cause to be made any connection between any pipeline, lines, wires, conduits, conductors, meters, transformers or other equipment in such manner as to prevent the correct registration of service by any metering device, or to otherwise use electricity, water or gas without the consent of the utility; or 
(4)  Supply or cause to be supplied any utility service to any person without such service first passing through the metering device provided by the utility for measuring and registering the quantity of service. 
(c)  Any person who is convicted of violating the provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of up to the maximum fine allowable under the ordinances of the city. 
(d)  If a civil action is brought by a utility against a person, the person may post a bond, cash or other security with the utility equal to the value of the service alleged to be unlawfully used or diverted. Upon posting of the bond or cash, and until final disposition of the case, the utility shall restore to the person any service which it may have terminated. 
(Code 2000, § 10-311; Ord. No. 530, 1-28-1985) 
Sec. 36-284. - Interference with fire hydrants. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person except one duly authorized by the city utility personnel or a member of the fire and rescue department to open, turn on or off, interfere with, attach any pipe or hose to, or connect anything with any fire hydrant or stop cock belonging to the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct access to any fire hydrant by placing around or thereon brick, lumber, dirt or other thing, or in any other manner obstructing access to a fire hydrant. 
(Code 2000, § 10-215) 
Sec. 36-285. - Buildings or structures on public ground. 
    Any person who shall maintain, erect or permit the erection of any building or other structure under his control upon any street, sidewalk, alley, avenue or other public grounds of the city shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 2000, § 10-218) 
Sec. 36-286. - Political advertising signs prohibited on rights-of-way; utility poles. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, an advertising sign is defined as any sign, poster or placard printed, painted, made or designed for the purpose of furthering or advertising the candidacy of any person who is or intends to become or may be a candidate for the election to any public office, whether such public office is in the local, state or federal government, or any subdivision thereof; and any sign designed for the purpose of aiding directly or indirectly in the sale of all commodities; any sign that is designed for the purpose of securing attendance of people in any event, open to and attended by the public, whether a fee is charged for such attendance or not. 
(b)  No person, firm or corporation shall erect or display any political advertising sign on any street or alley right-of-way, or upon any public utility easement within this city. 
(c)  No person, firm or corporation shall place, tack, nail, staple or glue any political advertising sign on any telephone, telegraph, electric or street lighting pole within this city. 
(d)  Any political advertising sign erected, placed or displayed in violation of the provisions hereof shall be a public nuisance. No property right shall exist in such sign erected, placed or displayed in violation of the provisions hereof, and such sign may be removed and destroyed by any person. 
(Code 2000, § 10-309) 
State Law reference- Trespass on posted property, 21 O.S. § 1835; trespass on certain private lands, 21 O.S. § 1835.2. 
Secs. 36-287-36-305. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - THEFT AND FRAUD 

Sec. 36-306. - Petit larceny; defined, prohibited. 
(a)  Petit larceny is the taking of personal property of value not exceeding $50.00 accomplished by fraud or stealth and with intent to deprive another thereof, but it does not include the taking of such property from the person of another. The crime and violation is complete when the accused takes control of the property with the intent to appropriate it to the use of the taker and with the intent not to purchase the property. 
(b)  Petit larceny is unlawful, and any person who commits larceny shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(c)  The removal of personal property from a rack or from any place where the personal property is displayed and concealing the personal property under the taker's clothing, or in a pocket of the taker's clothing, or concealing the personal property by the taker, in a basket or sack or other concealing device or container not furnished by the owner, with the intent to appropriate the property to the use of the taker, and with the intent not to purchase same, is an aspiration or taking of the personal property, even though the taking is discovered before the taker leaves the owner's premises. 
(Code 2000, § 10-201; Ord. No. 402, 12-2-1974) 
State Law reference- Larceny, 21 O.S. § 1701 et seq.; punishment of petit larceny, 21 O.S. § 1706. 
Sec. 36-307. - Harmful deception. 
    It is unlawful for any person knowingly to deceive another, whether by impersonation, misrepresentation, or otherwise, when such deception results in or contributes to the loss, damage, harm or injury of the person deceived or of a third party, or results in or contributes to the benefit of the deceiver. 
(Code 2000, § 10-417) 
State Law reference- False pretense, false percolations, cheats and frauds, 21 O.S. § 1500 et seq. 
Sec. 36-308. - False or bogus checks. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, with intent to cheat and defraud, to obtain or attempt to obtain from any person any money, property or valuable thing of the value of $50.00 or less by means of any false or bogus check or by any other written or printed or engraved instrument or spurious coin. The term "false or bogus check" shall include checks or orders given for money or property which are not honored on account of insufficient funds of the maker to pay same, as against the maker or drawer thereof. 
(b)  The making, drawing, issuing or delivering of a check, draft or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and the knowledge of insufficient funds in or credit with, such bank or other depository. Such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee the amount due thereon, together with the protest fees, and the check or order shall be presented for payment within 180 days after same is delivered and accepted. 
(Code 2000, § 10-418) 
State Law reference- Obtaining or attempting to obtain property by trick or deception, 21 O.S. § 1541.1. 
Sec. 36-309. - Swindling unlawful. 
    It is unlawful to get money or property from any other persons or businesses under false pretenses, deception, cheating or by any other fraudulent act. 
(Code 2000, § 10-419) 
State Law reference- False pretense, false percolations, cheats and frauds, 21 O.S. § 1500 et seq. 
Sec. 36-310. - False weights. 
    It is unlawful and an offense for any person within the corporate limits of the city to knowingly sell any commodity or article of merchandise and in the sale thereof make or give a false or short weight or measure, or for any person having in charge any scales or scale yards used in weighing any article to knowingly and willfully report any false or untrue weight whereby another person shall be defrauded or damaged. 
(Code 2000, § 10-220) 
State Law reference- Use of false weights and measures, 21 O.S. § 1551. 
Secs. 36-311-36-338. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TRESPASS 

Sec. 36-339. - Unlawful intrusion upon land. 
    It is unlawful for any person to intrude or squat upon any lot or piece of land within the city without a license or authority from the owner thereof, or to erect or occupy thereon any hut, hovel, shanty or other structure without such license or authority, or to place, erect or occupy within the bounds of any street, alley or avenue of the city, any hut, shanty, hovel, or other structure without authority of law or ordinance. 
(Code 2000, § 10-207) 
State Law reference- Trespass on posted property, 21 O.S. § 1835; trespass on certain private lands, 21 O.S. § 1835.2. 
Sec. 36-340. - Illegal entrance. 
    It is illegal for any person to enter upon the property of another or into an area or structure on such property (whether such property, area or structure is public or private), when such entrance is plainly forbidden by signs or any notice or when the property, area or structure is enclosed, except when such entrance is in the line of duty, or with the expressed, or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge, or otherwise by authority of law or ordinance. It is unlawful for any person to remain on the property of another after having been given notice, written or verbal, to leave by the owner or person in charge. 
(Code 2000, § 10-208) 
Sec. 36-341. - Trespass, defined; prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private property means any property other than public property. 
    Public property means that property which is dedicated to public use and over which the federal, state or municipal government or any subdivision thereof exercises control. 
    Trespass means each and every actual entry upon the premises of an owner or other person in lawful possession of the premises without the express or the implied consent of the owner or other person in lawful possession. Trespass shall also mean remaining upon the premises of an owner or other person in lawful possession after having been told to leave the premises by the owner, or the agent, or employee of the owner, or other person in lawful possession of the premises. Trespass shall also be defined as the act of remaining on private property at any time other than during posted hours of business operation after having been directed to vacate such premises by a police officer. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to persons, including employees, whose presence upon such premises is authorized by the owner or by a person in lawful possession of such premises nor shall the provisions of this sentence apply unless hours of business operations are posted upon such premises. Trespass shall also be defined as the act of returning to private property before the posted time of opening for business operation on the next business day after having been directed to vacate such premises under the terms of this subsection. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to trespass on private property. 
(Code 2000, § 10-213) 
State Law reference- Trespass on posted property, 21 O.S. § 1835; trespass on certain private lands, 21 O.S. § 1835.2. 
Sec. 36-342. - Entry on private property; trespass; evidence; burden of proof. 
(a)  No person shall make an entry with any vehicle upon real property owned or legally occupied by another without the owner's or occupant's consent except where such private property is provided as public parking and the general use of the property is not restricted by signs or proper markings. 
(b)  Where entry is made upon real property owned or legally occupied by another without the owner's or occupant's consent, except on unrestricted public parking, and is complained of by the owner or legal occupant of the premises, the burden is put upon the person making the entry to show that permission for such entry was given. 
(Code 2000, § 15-718) 
State Law reference- Trespass on posted property, 21 O.S. § 1835; trespass on certain private lands, 21 O.S. § 1835.2. 
Sec. 36-343. - Illegal trespass by vehicle. 
(a)  An unattended vehicle found to be in violation of section 36-342 may be impounded when the required complaint has been properly made and filed as provided in this section. 
(b)  If a violation of the provisions of section 36-342 occurs, the owner or legal occupant who complains shall sign a complaint against the person parking the vehicle on the owner's or legal occupant's property, or if the identity of the person parking the vehicle is unknown, then the complaint may be filed against the registered owner of the vehicle. The complaint shall be verified and shall allege that the complaining party is the owner or legal occupant of the property upon which the vehicle is parked or standing. 
(c)  Upon filing of the complaint by the property owner or legal occupant, and if there appears to be proper cause to believe the provisions of section 36-342 have been violated, the police department shall cause the vehicle to be impounded from the property and placed in storage. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1309) 
Sec. 36-344. - Parking on property of another. 
    It is unlawful for any person to park an automobile or other vehicle, or to place any structure or object on the driveway, yard, or property of another without the expressed or tacit consent of the owner or person in charge or by authority of law or ordinance. 
(Code 2000, § 10-214) 
Secs. 36-345-36-361. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 36-362. - Fences; electricity. 
    No person shall charge with electricity or electric current, or cause the same to be done, any fence abutting upon or constructed along any public thoroughfare within the limits of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 10-216) 
Sec. 36-363. - Smoking; offense. 
    It is an offense for any person to light any cigar, cigarette or pipe or to have any of these in a lighted or burning condition on any premises or parts of premises where smoking is forbidden and a notice of "No Smoking" is posted or placed in a conspicuous manner therein or thereupon in such a way that a reasonable person might see or notice the same. 
(Code 2000, § 10-310) 
State Law reference- Smoking in certain public areas and indoor workplaces prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1247. 
Secs. 36-364-36-384. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIREARMS AND EXPLOSIVES 

Sec. 36-385. - Fireworks regulated. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to sell, give away or barter, or to discharge, ignite, or in any manner aid, assist or abet in the discharging or igniting of any fireworks of any size, type or description. However, public fireworks displays may be exhibited under the supervision of the chief of police of the city, by persons experienced in the discharge of fireworks by first obtaining a permit for such exhibition from the city clerk and giving a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $10,000.00, conditioned to pay all damages to persons or property that may be injured or damaged as a result of the display. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the term "fireworks" shall be as defined in 68 O.S. § 1622. 
(Code 2000, § 10-303) 
State Law reference- Bottle rockets prohibited, 68 O.S. § 1624; state fireworks licenses required, 68 O.S. § 1621 et seq. 
Sec. 36-386. - Storing or keeping explosives. 
    It is unlawful for any person to store or keep within the city any nitroglycerin, dynamite, gunpowder, or any other highly explosive material or substance, except that gunpowder may be kept in quantities of not to exceed five pounds where the same is securely kept. 
(Code 2000, § 10-304) 
State Law reference- Storage of explosives, 63 O.S. § 128.2. 
Sec. 36-387. - Carrying weapons; exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to carry concealed upon or about his person any pistol, revolver, dagger, bowie knife, dirk knife, switchblade knife, spring-type knife, metal knuckle, or any other dangerous or deadly weapon or instrument except when doing so in the line of duty or as may be permitted by law. 
(Code 2000, § 10-305) 
State Law reference- Unlawful carry of weapons, 21 O.S. § 1272. 
Sec. 36-388. - Reckless conduct. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in reckless conduct while having in his possession any shotgun, rifle or pistol, such actions consisting of creating a situation of unreasonable risk and probability of death or great bodily harm to another, and demonstrating a conscious disregard for the safety of another person, except as may be permitted by state law. 
(Code 2000, § 10-306) 
State Law reference- Reckless conduct with weapons, 21 O.S. § 1289.11. 
Sec. 36-389. - Discharging firearms; exceptions. 
    No person shall discharge any species of firearm in the city except when doing so in the line of duty, when lawfully doing so in defense of oneself, of another person, or of property, or when otherwise authorized by law or ordinance. It is unlawful to discharge an air rifle or BB gun in the city. 
(Code 2000, § 10-307) 
State Law reference- Discharging firearm and throwing missiles in public place prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1364. 
Secs. 36-390-36-406. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 36-407-36-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CURFEW 

Sec. 36-426. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Custodian means any person over the age of 21 years who is in loco parentis to a minor. 
    Guardian means any person or other than a parent who has legal guardianship of a minor. 
    Minor means any person under the age of 18 years. 
    Parent means the natural or adoptive parent of a minor. 
    Public place means any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment or other lawful purpose. A public place shall include, but not be limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, drugstore, pool room, shopping center and any other place devoted to amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of the above. 
(Code 2000, § 10-412(a); Ord. No. 390, 6-29-1970; Ord. No. 397, 9-16-1974; Ord. No. 617, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 36-427. - Curfew hours designated; exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any minor to remain, wander, stroll or play in any public place on foot or to cruise about without a set destination in any vehicle in, about or upon any public place in the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Monday through Friday and between the hours of 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Saturday and Sunday unless: 
(1)  The minor is accompanied by a parent, guardian, custodian or other adult person having custody or control of such minor; 
(2)  The minor is on an emergency errand or specific business or activity directed or permitted by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of the minor; or 
(3)  Where the presence of such minor is connected with or required by some legitimate employment, trade, profession or occupation. 
(Code 2000, § 10-412(b); Ord. No. 390, 6-29-1970; Ord. No. 397, 9-16-1974; Ord. No. 617, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 36-428. - Responsibility of owner of public places. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation operating or having charge of any public place to knowingly permit or suffer the presence of minors between the hours of curfew designated in section 36-427. 
(Code 2000, § 10-412(c); Ord. No. 390, 6-29-1970; Ord. No. 397, 9-16-1974; Ord. No. 617, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 36-429. - Duty of parents, guardians and custodians; exceptions. 
    It is unlawful for any parent, guardian, custodian or other adult person having custody or control of any minor to suffer or permit or by inefficient control to allow such person to be on any public place within the city between the hours of curfew designated in section 36-427. The provisions of this section do not apply if: 
(1)  The minor is accompanied by a parent, guardian, custodian or other adult person having the care, custody or control of the minor; 
(2)  The minor is on an emergency errand or specific business or activity directed by his parent, guardian, custodian or other adult having the care and custody of the minor; or 
(3)  The parent guardian or other adult person herein has made a missing person notification to the city police department. 
(Code 2000, § 10-412(d); Ord. No. 390, 6-29-1970; Ord. No. 397, 9-16-1974; Ord. No. 617, 8-17-1992) 
Sec. 36-430. - Special exceptions granted by commission; procedure for taking minors into custody. 
    The council may permit by resolution or motion procedures for advance notice or registration with the city of special events or functions sponsored by churches, schools, clubs or other organizations which require minors to be out at a later time. The council may also prescribe the procedures for taking into custody minors found in violation of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 10-412(e); Ord. No. 390, 6-29-1970; Ord. No. 397, 9-16-1974; Ord. No. 617, 8-17-1992) 
Chapter 38 - PARKS, RECREATION AND CULTURAL AFFAIRS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 874 , § 1, adopted Sept. 16, 2013, amended Ch. 38 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 38, §§ 38-1-38-103, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference- Municipal parks and recreation, 11 O.S. § 33-101 et seq.; City-County Park and Recreation Act of Oklahoma, 19 O.S. § 1001 et seq.; Oklahoma Library Code, 65 O.S. § 1-101 et seq.; City-County Library Act, 65 O.S. § 151 et seq.; authority for municipalities to join in creation, development, operation, and maintenance of public libraries, 65 O.S. § 4-101. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City lake, as used in this chapter, refers to the city reservoir, located in the Northeast 1/4 of Section 22, Township 22 North, range 13 East, Rogers County, Oklahoma. 
    Public parks means all places owned by the city and used as city parks. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-2. - Compliance required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use any of such recreational facilities or to hunt, fish, swim or use any boat in connection with any of the recreational facilities owned or operated by the city without having complied with the rules and regulations promulgated by the board of commissioners of the city in connection therewith. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Secs. 38-3-38-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARK ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 38-21. - Control and management of city property and facilities. 
    All public park properties and recreation facilities within the jurisdiction of the City of Collinsville, Oklahoma, together with all property or facilities which may be hereafter acquired or used for park and recreation purposes, shall be under the management, care, and control of the city commission. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Creation and powers of recreation boards and commissions, 11 O.S. § 33-105. 
Sec. 38-22. - Park advisory board appointed. 
    The city park board is composed of five qualified voters of the city, to be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the board of commissioners. One of the members appointed shall be designated by the mayor as chairman. Every year, at the time prescribed for the beginning of the term for new members, or as soon as is practicable thereafter, the park advisory board shall elect a vice chairman and secretary. 
    The term of office of the members shall be coterminous with the terms of the mayor and board of commissioners, unless removed by a vote of the board of commissioners prior thereto, and the park advisory board members shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. Park board members shall possess the same qualifications and be subject to the same disqualifications provided by law for commissioners of the city and shall serve without compensation. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
State Law reference- Creation and powers of recreation boards and commissions, 11 O.S. § 33-105. 
Sec. 38-23. - Meetings and quorum. 
    The board shall determine the time and place of its regular monthly meetings, and the chairman or any four members may call special meeting of the board. 
    A majority of a quorum must vote aye or nay on each motion properly before the board for action or such motion shall not carry or be denied. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-24. - Appropriation and disposition of funds. 
    The duties of the park advisory board shall be as follows, to wit: 
(1)  Consider and recommend for city commission approval, acceptance, acquisition or disposal of park property, both real and personal; 
(2)  Consider and recommend for city commission approval, future improvements to park property, both real and personal, and provide an estimate of the capital needs; 
(3)  Consider and recommend for city commission approval, adoption or repeal of park rules and regulations; and 
(4)  Consider and recommend for city staff implementation of park events and programs. 
(5)  The park board shall render to the board of commissioners quarterly reports for the quarters ending on the last day of March, June, September and December, or as soon after the end of each quarter as practicable. 
    In the performance of the board duties as outlined about the board shall be authorized to request of the city manager provision of staff personnel as well as engineering, financial, legal and/or recreation assistance and guidance from the respective departments within the city. 
    Except for purpose of inquiry, the board or individual members thereof shall not give orders to any employee of the park department either publicly or privately, or to any other employee of the City of Collinsville, Oklahoma. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-25. - Members not to hold other office. 
    Members of the park advisory board shall not hold any other office or position in city government or hold office or position with the Collinsville Municipal Authority. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-26. - Removal of members. 
    Any park advisory board member who is absent for more than one-half of all regular meetings of the board held within any period of four consecutive calendar months within which regular meetings are held each month, or who moves from the city limits of Collinsville, shall thereupon automatically cease to hold office without hearing or action by the commission and his/her replacement shall be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the board of commissioners. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Secs. 38-27-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK RULES AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 38-31. - Merchandising. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale any merchandise in any of the public parks of the City of Collinsville without prior approval by the city. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-32. - Advertising. 
    No person shall advertise in any manner or distribute or hand out any circular, handbill or poster of any kind or of any commodity or other thing in any public park. It shall be unlawful to affix any circular, handbill, poster or sign or announcement of any kind on any tree, lamppost, hydrant, curbstone, sidewalk, coping, flagstone, fence, wall, building or other place in any public park or on any street, avenue, or alley or other public grounds under the supervision of the city. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-33. - Disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person at any time to lawfully or maliciously disturb the public peace or quietude or the life, health or safety of any individual in any manner by making unnecessary or inappropriate noise; by any disorderly conduct interrupting disquieting or disrupting any lawful congregation or assembly of people in any City of Collinsville Park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-34. - Firearms. 
    No person shall discharge any firearms in any public park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-35. - Defacing park property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to destroy, damage, or deface any park property, buildings, equipment, fixtures, trees, or grounds. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-36. - Speed. 
    No person shall drive or ride at a greater rate of speed than 15 miles an hour within any public park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-37. - Building fires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build a fire for any purpose in any public park except for cooking food with self-contained grills or in structures provided by the City of Collinsville for cooking in the park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-38. - Animals at large. 
    No person shall permit any animals to run at large in any public park of the city. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-39. - Littering. 
    It shall be an offense for any person to throw, place, leave, scatter or otherwise deposit any papers, boxes, cartons, or rubbish of any kind on any of the grounds, walks, paths, or places in any public park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-40. - General offenses. 
    Any prohibited act or conduct which constitutes an offense as set forth in the City of Collinsville Code of Ordinances shall be an offense when such a conduct is committed in any public park. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-41. - Park curfew. 
    Unless otherwise provided for by action upon motion of the city commission allowing exception to the time limits herein provided for, all public parks of the city, as defined within this chapter, shall be closed for public use between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. every day of the week. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Secs. 38-42-38-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY LAKE 

Sec. 38-101. - State fishing license required. 
    Any person holding a fishing license under state law that has not expired or is otherwise lawfully permitted to fish under the laws of the state shall be permitted to fish in and upon the city lake. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-102. - Prohibitions on fishing. 
    Fishing by the use of trot lines or throw lines is prohibited, and fishing in the city lake by any means other than a pole and line is prohibited. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-103. - Swimming and boat use prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use a boat upon the lake or to swim or wade. 
( Ord. No. 874 , § 1, 9-16-2013) 
Sec. 38-104. - Motorized boat use prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use a motorized boat on the City Lake or to swim or wade in the City Lake. 
( Ord. No. 901, § 1, 5-16-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 901 , § 1, adopted May 16, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 38-107. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 38-104. 
Sec. 38-105. - Use of City Lake Trails. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a horse on the City Lake Trails or to operate a motorized vehicle on the City Lake Trails. 
( Ord. No. 901, § 1, 5-16-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 901 , § 1, adopted May 16, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 38-108. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 38-105. 
Sec. 38-106. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided for in section 1-11 of this Code for each offense. 
( Ord. No. 901, § 1, 5-16-2016 ; Ord. No. 903, § 1, 7-5-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 901 , § 1, adopted May 16, 2016, set out provisions intended for use as § 38-109. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 38-106. 
Chapter 40 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 900 , § 1, adopted May 2, 2016, repealed former Ch. 40, §§ 40-1-40-35, and enacted a new Ch. 40 as set out herein. The former chapter pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 2000, §§ 9-201-9-216. 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate peddlers and solicitors, 11 O.S. § 22-106, 47 O.S. § 434; Transient Merchant Licensing Act relative to counties, 19 O.S. § 1608 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 40-1-40-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 40-21. - Definitions. 
    The listed terms and phrases, as used in this section, shall be defined as follows: 
    License means the written authority of the city, issued by its duly authorized agent, employee or officer, conferring permission on some person to pursue and exercise a trade, occupation, or business for a definite period of time within the limits of the city, under the conditions prescribed by ordinance. 
    Peddle means to travel from house to house, door to door, street to street, or place to place, carrying, conveying, or transporting goods, wares, or merchandise for the purpose of offering and exposing the same for sale. 
    Peddler means any person who peddles. 
    Solicit includes any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Selling or offering for sale, or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods or services of any kind character or description; 
(2)  Requesting directly or indirectly contributions of funds on the plea or representation that such contributions will be used for a charitable purpose; 
(3)  Peddling as defined in this section. 
    Solicitor means any person who solicits. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-22. - Issuance. 
(a)  The issuance of all licenses, collection of all license fees, inspection of all licenses, and the enforcement of license conditions and revocation of licenses, shall be under the jurisdiction of the city clerk, except where such duties are placed elsewhere by the ordinance prescribing the particular license. 
(b)  No license for soliciting shall be issued until a satisfactory application has been submitted and approved, the required license fee has been paid to the city clerk and all other conditions and requirements under this section have been satisfied. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-23. - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, either as principal, officer, agent, servant or employee, to engage in any of the callings, trades, professions or occupations for which a license is required, in this section, including soliciting, without first paying to the city clerk the required fee and procuring a license as required by this section from the city clerk. This section shall not apply to non-profit youth organizations engaging in door-to-door solicitation. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-24. - Application required. 
    Applicants for a solicitor's license must complete and submit an application provided by the city clerk which shall include no less than the following information and attachments: 
(1)  Name and current address of the individual, business, or organization, to include phone and email contact information; 
(2)  Details of solicitation, to include beginning and end date and description of goods or services to be sold; 
(3)  Detailed personal information and physical description of solicitor(s); 
(4)  Social Security number, current, valid driver's license or state issued identification card of solicitor; 
(5)  Vehicle information relating to vehicles used in the solicitation, to include make, model, year, tag number and a copy of vehicle's current insurance verification; 
(6)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within the past five years; 
(7)  Valid and current State of Oklahoma sales tax permit information, unless the applicant can prove to the city clerk's satisfaction that such permit is not mandated under the definition of the State Tax Code. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-25. - Display of license. 
    All persons issued a license under this section shall at all times display the license prominently on their person, shall carry at least one form of photo identification, and shall produce the license and photo identification for inspection and review at any time upon request by any city official, law enforcement officer or person to whom the solicitor is attempting to solicit or peddle. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-26. - No knock list. 
(a)  The city clerk shall prepare and maintain a list of all residents within the city who desire to prevent soliciting and peddling at their residence which shall be known as the no knock list. Residents of the city who desire to have their addresses placed on the no knock list may do so by contacting the city clerk's office. 
(b)  Solicitors must obtain a copy of the no knock list from the city clerk's office at the time they obtain a license, and are expressly prohibited from soliciting or peddling at any residence listed on the no knock list. Contacting residents in disregard of the no knock list may result in revocation of a solicitor's license and/or assessment of a fine. 
(c)  This provision shall not apply to non-profit organizations, groups and associations. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-27. - Prohibited acts. 
    The following acts are prohibited and may result in the revocation of any person's license: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for a solicitor to ring the bell, or knock on the door, or otherwise attempt to gain admittance for the purpose of soliciting at a residence or dwelling which is listed on the no knock list or upon which a sign stating "no solicitors," "no trespassers," or words of similar import indicating such persons are not wanted on the premises, is painted, affixed or otherwise plainly displayed to public view either on or near the primary entrance of the residence. This paragraph shall not apply to any solicitor who gains admittance to a residence either by invitation or consent of the residence's occupant. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to solicit between the hours of dusk and 9:00 a.m. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-28. - License record. 
    The city clerk shall maintain a record of all solicitor licenses issued under this section showing the date of the issuance, the person to whom the license was issued and the time period covered by the license. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-29. - License period and fee schedule. 
(a)  The license fee which shall be charged by the city clerk for a solicitor license shall include the cost of a background check and shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  No license fee shall be charged to a non-profit organization. A non-profit organization is defined as any organization or corporation organized not for profit but for the promotion of the welfare or education of others and which is exempt from federal and/or state income tax by virtue of its non-profit status. A registration form shall be completed and submitted whenever members or representatives of a non-profit will be soliciting or peddling within the city. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-30. - Transfer of license prohibited. 
    No solicitor license may be sold or otherwise transferred. Each license is issued on consideration of the fitness of an applicant to hold that license and shall not be transferred. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-31. - Replacement of lost license. 
    Whenever an original license has been lost or destroyed, the city clerk shall issue a duplicate license. The fee for a duplicate license shall be established by resolution of the city council. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-32. - Grounds for denial or revocation of license. 
    Licenses issued under the provisions of this section may be denied or revoked by the city clerk for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in application for license; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in the course of carrying on the business as a solicitor, exhibitor, or as a canvasser; 
(3)  Conviction of any felony or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude within the past five years; 
(4)  Conducting the business of soliciting in an unlawful manner, or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace, or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. This shall include soliciting at residences listed on the no knock list or those plainly displaying a no soliciting or no trespassing sign as provided for herein. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-33. - Process of revocation or denial of license and appeal. 
(a)  All licenses issued by the city shall be subject to revocation by the city clerk upon any breach of any condition prescribed by ordinance for the regulation of such licensed occupation or in the event such licensee operates such licensed occupation or business in violation of the laws of the city or the state, or in violation of any law or regulation of the United States government. 
(b)  The city clerk's office shall give notice either in person, by telephone, mail or email to the licensee of the denial or revocation of their license. If mailed, the notice shall be sent to the address listed on the application or license. The license shall stand revoked or denied from the time notice is made to the licensee either in person or by telephone or is received by mail by the licensee. 
(c)  Any licensee may appeal a denial or revocation to the city manager within ten days after delivery or receipt of the notice by filing a written request with the city clerk for a hearing. The hearing shall be held by the city manager or his or her designee. The appealing licensee may be represented by counsel. The hearing shall be conducted in an informal manner, but no license shall be revoked or denied except upon a preponderance of the evidence. The city manager or his or her designee may affirm, modify or vacate the order of revocation or denial, and his or her decision shall be final. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Sec. 40-34. - Penalty. 
    Any person who engages in soliciting or peddling without a valid license or permit as required, or who violates any provision of this section, is guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be fined, including costs as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. Every day upon which a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
( Ord. No. 900, § 1, 5-2-2016 ) 
Chapter 42 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal zoning and planning authority, 11 O.S. § 43-101; municipal buildings, zoning, and planning generally, 11 O.S. § 41-101 et seq.; city-county planning and zoning, 19 O.S. § 866.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - State comprehensive plan adopted. 
    The city has adopted the Collinsville Comprehensive Plan: 2030 Text and Map as the official master plan of the city. A copy of the plan is available in the office of the city clerk. 
(Res. No. 2009-02, 2-16-2009) 
Secs. 42-2-42-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 42-21. - Appointment of members; terms; compensation; vacancies. 
(a)  There is hereby created in the city a city planning commission to be composed of five members. Of the members first appointed to this commission, the mayor shall nominate two members of such commission to serve for a period of one year, two members to serve for a term of two years and one member to serve for a period of three years. Such nominees shall be confirmed by a majority of the board of commissioners of the city. The mayor, upon nominating such initial commissioners, shall designate which of the commissioners shall serve for a period of one year and which shall serve for a period of two years, and which shall serve for a period of three years. 
(b)  The members of the commission shall be appointed from residents of the city. In appointments, an effort shall be made to secure the services of persons best qualified to plan for the future growth, development and improvement of the city and in the orderly development of city planning for the city as a whole. 
(c)  The members of the city planning commission shall serve without salary, and in the event of a vacancy on the commission for any reason, a successor shall be appointed as herein provided for the unexpired term only of such vacancy. 
(Code 2000, § 12-101) 
State Law reference- Municipal planning commissions generally, appointment authorized, 11 O.S. § 45-101 et seq.; members, compensation, terms, 11 O.S. § 45-102. 
Sec. 42-22. - Officers; election and term. 
    Immediately after the appointment and qualification of the members of the commission, the commission shall meet and elect one of their number as chairman and one of their number as secretary, each elected for a term of one year, or until their successors are elected and qualified. 
(Code 2000, § 12-102) 
Sec. 42-23. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city planning commission shall prescribe rules and regulations governing and controlling the transaction of business before it, and shall determine a date each month for regular meetings. Special meetings may be called at any time by the chairman of the commission. 
(Code 2000, § 12-103) 
Sec. 42-24. - Duties and powers. 
(a)  The duties and powers of the planning commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  To investigate and recommend to the mayor and board of commissioners suitable zoning ordinances for the city; 
(2)  To investigate and make recommendations concerning the physical development growth, improvement, convenience and beautification of the city; 
(3)  To investigate all matters relating to the location and development of parks, recreation places, streets, public grounds, location and design of public buildings and public structures, and to make report of their findings on any proposed or contemplated project relative to any of the above matters to the board of commissioners of the city; 
(4)  Upon the enactment of zoning ordinances by the city, the planning commission shall conduct any hearings necessary to determine injustices, variation, waiver or modification of such zoning ordinances with reference to any particular property or properties; and 
(5)  To conduct hearings and make recommendations to the board of commissioners of the city concerning waiver of any of the ordinances of the city applying to the use to which private property in the city may be put, and the area, height and use of buildings on properties. 
(b)  All findings and recommendations of the city planning commission affecting private property shall be submitted in writing to the board of commissioners of the city for their examination, approval or rejection. 
(Code 2000, § 12-104) 
State Law reference- Duties and powers of municipal planning commissions, employees of commission, 11 O.S. § 45-103. 
Sec. 42-25. - Procedure. 
    All projects or matters that fall within the purview of the duties of the city planning commission, as herein specified, that may come before the board of commissioners of the city shall be referred to the city planning commission for investigation and report before any final action shall be taken thereon. However, if the city planning commission shall fail to make an investigation and report on any matter or subject referred to it for a period of 60 days, such failure shall be considered a refusal to approve the proposed plan or project, and the board of commissioners may thereupon act upon such proposal, plan or project as though such matter had not been referred to the planning commission. 
(Code 2000, § 12-105) 
Sec. 42-26. - Plats and subdivisions. 
    No platting of unplatted property in the city, no replatting of any existing subdivision in the city and no platting or subdivision of property adjoining the city shall be permitted until such plat or resubdivision shall be presented to the city planning commission, and a hearing had thereon. 
(Code 2000, § 12-106) 
State Law reference- Planning commission review of public improvements and plats of land, 11 O.S. § 45-104. 
Sec. 42-27. - Expenditures. 
    The city planning commission shall as required make application to the board of commissioners of the city for the funds that may be necessary for such planning commission to expend in order to carry out its duties as herein specified. The planning commission shall make application to the board of commissioners for an appropriation to be set up for its use in carrying out its duties, and the city may include such appropriation in its estimate or budget. 
(Code 2000, § 12-107) 
Secs. 42-28-42-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGIONAL PLANNING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-58. - Purpose and necessity. 
    The purpose of this article shall be to assure the orderly development of the area surrounding the city; to lessen congestion in the streets; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to promote the health and the general welfare of the community; to provide adequate light and air; to prevent overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of population; to create a comprehensive and stable pattern of land uses on which to plan for transportation, water supply, sewerage, schools, parks and other public requirements; and, with the view of conserving the value of buildings and other improvements, to encourage the most appropriate use of land throughout such area. 
(Code 2000, § 12-202) 
Sec. 42-59. - Nature of regional plan and defining jurisdiction. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all land outside of the incorporated limits of the city, and within a distance of three miles outside such corporate limits. This article shall govern the location, use, size and design of public buildings, statues, memorials, parks, parkways, streets and boulevards, playgrounds, public grounds, bridges and other public structures and improvements, and the area and open spaces above buildings or structures, and the approval or rejection of all plans, plats or replats of land laid out in lots or plats, and the streets, alleys and other portions of land intended to be dedicated to public or private use within such area. 
(Code 2000, § 12-203) 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction of regional planning commissions, 11 O.S. § 46-102. 
Sec. 42-60. - Future tracts within three miles of city limits. 
    Whenever any lot, parcel or tract of land outside three miles of the corporate limits of the city which by annexation or otherwise shall come within three miles of the corporate limits of the city, such area or tract of land upon coming within such area shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 12-204) 
Secs. 42-61-42-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 42-79. - Membership. 
    Membership of the regional planning commission of the city shall be the mayor of the city, the duly appointed, qualified and acting city engineer, the chairman of the board of the county commissioners, and the county engineer, who shall all serve as members of the commission. The regional planning commission shall also include the city planning commission of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 12-205) 
State Law reference- Regional planning commissions generally, authority for appointment, 11 O.S. § 46-101. 
Sec. 42-80. - Compensation. 
    No member of the commission shall receive any item, money or other thing of value for his services as a member of the commission, and all members shall serve without pay. 
(Code 2000, § 12-206) 
State Law reference- Members of regional planning commissions to serve without pay, 11 O.S. § 46-101. 
Sec. 42-81. - Procedures. 
    The regional planning commission of the city shall promulgate and make rules and regulations under and by which such commission shall function, and shall determine and elect its proper officers, shall prescribe such officers' duties and hire employees for the functions of such planning commission, as authorized by state law. The commission shall determine all orders of business before the commission and shall set and determine dates and places of meetings, both regular and special, as they may deem proper and necessary. 
(Code 2000, § 12-207) 
State Law reference- Procedure for review of public improvements and plats of land by regional planning commissions, 11 O.S. § 46-104 
Sec. 42-82. - Powers of commission. 
(a)  The regional planning commission of the city shall be responsible for the orderly development and the betterment of the area coming under its jurisdiction, as herein defined, and to that end shall make or cause to be made, surveys, plats, maps and plans of areas coming within the jurisdiction of such commission. 
(b)  Before final action shall be taken by the city government or the county government or any department thereof on the location and design of any public building, statute, memorial, park, parkway, street or boulevard, playground, public grounds or bridges within such regional district, the location and design of any of such matters shall be investigated and reported upon to the city commission by the regional planning commission. 
(c)  Before the filing of any plans, plats or replats of lands in any such area shall be made, all the plans, plats or replats shall first be submitted to the regional planning commission for consideration and approval or rejection. To this end the regional planning commission may make or cause to be made regulations governing the location, construction standards and sizes of streets, alleys, utility rights-of-way or other portions of such lands intended to be dedicated to public or private use. 
(d)  In addition to the powers herein granted, the regional planning commission shall have all powers, authority and functions as may be permitted or provided by state law relating to such subject. 
(Code 2000, § 12-208) 
State Law reference- Duties and powers of regional planning commissions, 11 O.S. § 46-103. 
Sec. 42-83. - Public hearings required. 
(a)  The board of commissioners of the city may by ordinance amend, change or repeal this article or any part thereof. However, before the board of commissioners of the city shall amend, change or repeal this article or any part thereof, it shall by resolution request the regional planning commission to submit its recommendations on such proposed amendment, change or repeal. Upon receiving such request, the regional planning commission shall hold a public hearing thereon, which hearing may be adjourned from time to time. After considering the regional planning commission's recommendation at such public hearing, for which public notice shall be given, the board of commissioners of the city may approve such recommendations in whole or in part, or return such recommendations to the regional planning commission for further consideration. 
(b)  The regional planning commission may, upon its own initiative, hold at least one public hearing on any proposed amendment, change or repeal of this article or any part thereof, and any recommendations of the regional planning commission in connection therewith shall be by resolution transmitted to the board of commissioners of the city. The board of commissioners shall consider and act upon such recommendations in the same manner as is herein set forth for recommendations requested by the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Notice of a public hearing as herein required shall conform to state law. 
(Code 2000, § 12-209) 
Sec. 42-84. - Fees. 
    Upon the filing of an application for consideration by the regional planning commission, the property owner or his duly authorized representative shall pay a nonrefundable filing fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule to the regional planning commission by payment of the fee to the city clerk, all of such fees to be credited to the general fund of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 12-210) 
Sec. 42-85. - Applications. 
    Every application to be considered by the regional planning commission shall be accompanied by: 
(1)  A plat showing the shape and dimensions of the lot to be built upon or subdivided, the exact size and location on such lot of existing buildings and structures, and the lines within which the proposed building or structures shall be erected or altered; and 
(2)  The plat shall also show the shape, size and location of all streets, alleys or other public or private dedications, the proposed location and type of water supply and sewage disposal facilities, and such other information with regard to such lots and the neighboring lots in such area and their use as may be necessary to determine if such plat shows an orderly and beneficial development of the area set forth on such plat, including the location and design of public buildings and structures. 
(Code 2000, § 12-211) 
Secs. 42-86-42-113. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CORRIDOR APPEARANCE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 42-114. - Purpose and intent. 
    The city has created corridor appearance districts for the purpose of promoting the redevelopment and expansion of existing businesses in the downtown shopping district, to encourage and attract a variety of new retail, service, and higher density residential uses, and to create an area to provide residential, commercial and public attractions of educational, scientific, and cultural significance as stated in the approved and adopted comprehensive plan. 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(A); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § A, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 42-115. - Location. 
    The boundaries of the corridor appearance districts are described in five metes and bounds descriptions available in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(B); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § B, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 42-116. - Exemptions. 
    Residential zoning districts, planned unit developments (PUDs); specific use permits, and other zoning classifications or districts with restrictive covenants or development text, when determined to meet the corridor appearance district guidelines at the time of zoning approval, are exempted from the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(C); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § C, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 42-117. - Issuance of building permits in the corridor appearance district. 
    Prior to the construction or reconstruction of any structure, exterior remodeling, placement of exterior lighting or signs, or any proposed construction requiring the issuance of a building permit other than a small job permit, an application shall be made and be subject to the corridor appearance district guidelines and approval of the planning commission 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(D); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § D, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 42-118. - Corridor appearance district development guidelines. 
(a)  The city planning commission has adopted corridor theme appearance district development guidelines pursuant to this article. 
(b)  The guidelines are designed to accommodate those of the corridor appearance districts and also provide for a prairie commercial style which allows for a mixture of the various styles and themes within the corridor appearance districts. Architectural designs, color schemes, building materials, building location, off-street parking facilities, and landscaping features contributing to the overall appearance of structures within the corridor appearance district shall show overall compatibility with the nearby neighborhoods. 
(c)  The corridor appearance district guidelines and specific conditions emanating there from are to be measured in the context of, first, economic viability; second, livability; and third, compatibility. 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(E); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § E, 4-4-2005) 
Sec. 42-119. - Detailed site plan approval. 
    A detailed site plan in conformance with the corridor appearance district guidelines shall be required. Evaluation of the conformance will be contingent upon compliance with the guidelines or approved alternatives for the following appearance criteria: 
(1)  Appearance/design; 
(2)  Building materials; 
(3)  Landscaping and/or water features; 
(4)  Fencing; 
(5)  Signage; 
(6)  Lighting; 
(7)  Storage/outbuilding. 
(Code 2000, § 12-108(F); Ord. No. 760, 4-4-2005; Ord. No. 761, § F, 4-4-2005) 
Chapter 44 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Pawnshop Act, 59 O.S. § 1501 et seq.; Oklahoma Junkyard and Scrap Metal Processing Facility Control Act, 69 O.S. § 1251; Oklahoma Scrap Metal Dealers Act, 59 O.S. § 1421 et seq.; Precious Metal and Gem Dealer Licensing Act, 59 O.S. § 1521 et seq.; used motor vehicle and parts dealers, 47 O.S. § 581 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 44-1. - Occupation license required. 
    Unless specifically provided otherwise in this chapters, all secondhand goods dealers shall be required to obtain a city occupational license pursuant to chapter 12. 
Secs. 44-2-44-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUNK AND JUNK DEALERS 

Sec. 44-21. - Junk dealers to keep records. 
    Any person operating a junk shop shall keep a record of all junk, scrap iron or other things bought, showing date, person selling and the article bought. The shop shall be maintained within a building or space enclosed with solid walls not less than seven feet high and all of the junk shall be kept inside of the walls or building. 
(Code 2000, § 9-120) 
Secs. 44-22-44-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 44-46. - Pawnbroker to comply with provisions. 
    Any person operating a pawnshop shall: 
(1)  Keep a register of all pawned goods, wares or merchandise in which he shall enter the vendor's name, the article pawned and the date of the same; 
(2)  Give at least 30 days' notice to any person before any merchandise given by such person under any pledge or pawn may be forfeited to the operator; 
(3)  Deliver any stolen merchandise to the police upon demand; 
(4)  Not pledge or receive any goods on pledge to any minor; 
(5)  Close his place of business at dark and keep the same closed until sunrise; and 
(6)  Keep his register of pledged goods subject to the inspection of the chief of police at any time on demand. 
(Code 2000, § 9-121) 
Chapter 48 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Solid Waste Management Act, 27A O.S. § 2-10-101 et seq.; authority of municipalities to displace private collection companies, 19 O.S. § 365; littering of highways and public property prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1753.3; putting glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans and other substances on highway prohibited, 47 O.S. § 11-1110. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 48-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means all waste matter of animals, fowls, vegetables, fruit or food accumulating in any public or private place. 
    Residential unit means any residence or dwelling, or portion thereof, served by electric or water meters, or both. 
    Rubbish means all waste matter other than garbage, as defined in this section. 
    Service unit shall be construed to mean a daily average amount of garbage or rubbish, or both, not to exceed whichever of the following is the most applicable: 
(1)  The contents of two garbage cans, each not to exceed a greater capacity than 32 gallons; 
(2)  15 cubic feet of rubbish; or 
(3)  The contents of one garbage can and eight cubic feet of rubbish. 
(Code 2000, § 17-401; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Secs. 48-2-48-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REFUSE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

Sec. 48-21. - Accumulation of garbage and rubbish. 
    No person shall deposit or place any garbage or rubbish in any alley, street or other public place within the city, nor shall any person deposit or place any garbage or rubbish upon private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the limits of the city unless the same shall be enclosed in a suitable container as herein defined. 
(Code 2000, § 17-402; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Sec. 48-22. - Approved containers. 
(a)  Containers for the deposit and storage of garbage or rubbish shall be portable with handles, and constructed of galvanized metal or equivalent in such a manner as to be strong, not easily corrodible, shall be rodentproof, flyproof and shall have a tightfitting lid. 
(b)  The cover for such container shall be kept continuously on the container except when depositing or removing the contents of such container. 
(c)  Containers shall have a capacity of not more than 32 gallons, or less than 20 gallons, and if one container is not sufficient to hold the quantity of garbage and rubbish accumulating between collections, another (not to exceed 32 gallons) for such purpose shall be provided by the person occupying the premises. 
(d)  Garbage container surfaces shall be kept free of garbage accumulation by wrapping in paper all garbage placed in the container, and by washing the container at least once each week. 
(e)  Business establishments may provide a two-yard or three-yard capacity dumpster or containers with handles, portable, and constructed of galvanized metal or equivalent in such a manner as to be strong, not easily corrodible, shall be rodentproof and flyproof and shall have a tightfitting lid. 
(f)  Containers shall be located and maintained so as not to create a fire hazard. 
(g)  Rubbish consisting of wood shall be bundled in lengths not to exceed four feet and not to exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
(Code 2000, § 17-403; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Sec. 48-23. - Collection of garbage and rubbish; fees. 
(a)  No person, firm or corporation, other than the duly authorized employees of the city, shall collect, transport or dispose of garbage or rubbish within the city limits. 
(b)  Garbage and rubbish shall be collected from each residence and business as scheduled by the city. 
(c)  Garbage and rubbish containers shall be placed in a convenient location for access and collection by the persons authorized by the city to make such collections. 
(Code 2000, § 17-404; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Sec. 48-24. - Disposal of garbage and rubbish. 
(a)  Disposal of all garbage and rubbish collected within the city shall be by sanitary landfill and cover, the method and place of disposal to be determined by the board of commissioners of the city. 
(b)  The disposal of garbage or rubbish by an individual, householder or establishment in any place, private or public, within the city limits, except at the disposal grounds designated by the board of commissioners, is prohibited. 
(c)  All junk, garbage or refuse or other materials placed in or on the disposal area is the property of the city and no person shall be allowed to separate and collect, carry off or dispose of the same except by written consent and direction of the board of commissioners of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 17-406; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Sec. 48-25. - Keeping of uncollected garbage unlawful. 
    The keeping of garbage after the regular collection date, as established by this article, shall be unlawful, and failure of the city to collect such garbage in the regular manner due to the refusal or failure of the person liable for the payment of such garbage service charges to pay the same shall be no excuse or defense. 
(Code 2000, § 17-408; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982) 
Sec. 48-26. - Service charges. 
(a)  There shall be charged, assessed and collected from each residential unit within the city limits charges as provided in the city fee schedule. The city clerk shall collect garbage and rubbish fees, either by adding the amount thereof to the electric or water bill of each person liable for the payment of such fees as a separate item on such electric or water bill, or by such other means as the board of commissioners may determine. 
(b)  No garbage or rubbish shall be collected from any premises where the person liable for the payment of the garbage collection fees is in arrears in the payment of such fees for a period of one month. 
(c)  Any person, whether resident or nonresident of the city, shall have the privilege of using the disposal area for garbage and/or rubbish as established by the city and each such person shall pay a fee as set forth by the board of commissioners. The fees are to be paid to the attendant on duty at the time such garbage or rubbish is deposited in the disposal area, as herein defined. 
(Code 2000, § 17-407; Ord. No. 510, 5-24-1982; Ord. No. 814, § 1, 7-7-2008) 
Sec. 48-27. - Private use of disposal area; fees. 
    Any person shall have a once-per-month privilege of using the disposal area for a pickup load or the equivalent of garbage or rubbish as established by the city, who can produce a valid driver's license or other identification and a stub from the current city utility bill showing that they are paying a trash collection fee and will not be charged at the landfill for use as established by the city. The utility bill will be punched by a landfill attendant to show that the once-per-month privilege has been exercised. Thereafter, subsequent loads taken by that household or business to the landfill must be paid for at the current rates as set by the city. Any other such person, business or contractor, resident or nonresident, shall pay the fee as set forth by the city. 
(Code 2000, § 17-409; Ord. of 12-10-1973; Ord. No. 581, 3-19-1990; Ord. No. 586, 5-29-1990) 
Secs. 48-28-48-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RECYCLING 

Sec. 48-58. - Mandatory curbside separation.
