(a)  Business establishments and residential units within the city shall be required to separate at the curbside, or other place of normal collection, from garbage or rubbish place for collection by the city, the following items: 
Aluminum cans 
Aluminum foil 
Glass: clear, brown and green 
Newspaper 
Cardboard (corrugated only at this time) 
Scrap paper 
Computer paper 
Automobile batteries 
Plastic: PETE 1, HDPE 2 
Polystyrene foam 
Tin cans 
(b)  Any person who, by reason of being aged or handicapped, is unable to accomplish the separation of refuse as herein required may, upon application to the board of commissioners of the city, be excepted from the mandatory provisions hereof upon a finding of the board of commissioners that such person is, by reason of a determined infirmity arising from age or handicap, mentally or physically unable to accomplish the refuse separation herein mandated. 
(Ord. No. 591, 9-10-1990; Ord. No. 594, 10-22-1990; Ord. No. 595, 10-22-1990) 
Sec. 48-59. - Scavenging prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and an offense for any person to scavenge any of the aforestated recyclables hereby mandated to be separated and placed at the curbside or other appropriate collection place, separated from other refuse. It is further declared to be unlawful and an offense for any person, without having prior authorization therefor, to dump any refuse in a public or private dumpster. 
(Ord. No. 591, 9-10-1990; Ord. No. 594, 10-22-1990; Ord. No. 595, 10-22-1990) 
Sec. 48-60. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person, as defined in this Code, unless excepted as provided under the Code provisions relating thereto, willfully failing or refusing to perform the curbside separation as required by this section shall, in lieu of any other penalty therefor, be assessed and pay for refuse collection and disposal service an amount equal to twice the charge otherwise pertaining at such time for the refuse collection and disposal service being provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 591, 9-10-1990; Ord. No. 594, 10-22-1990; Ord. No. 595, 10-22-1990) 
Chapter 50 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General powers of municipalities relative to streets, roads and public ways, 11 O.S. § 36-101 et seq.; municipal authority to regulate street use, 47 O.S. § 1148; municipal authority to regulate processions and assemblages on highways, 47 O.S. § 15-102; authority to disperse lawful processions during emergency, 21 O.S. § 1321.8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Grades reserved. 
    The following ordinances, regarding street and sidewalk grades, datum plans and elevations, are saved from repeal and shall continue in full force and effect until otherwise specifically provided by the board of commissioners: 
Ordinance No. 51, dated 9-6-1911 
Ordinance No. 53, dated 9-11-1911 
Ordinance No. 54, dated 9-11-1911 
(Code 2000, § 14-101) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to establish and change street grades, 11 O.S. § 36-101. 
Secs. 50-2-50-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET AND SIDEWALK OBSTRUCTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-21. - Sidewalk and gutter to be kept clean, in good repair. 
    It is the duty of the occupant of any lot or piece of ground abutting upon any street where there is a sidewalk or gutter on the street to keep such sidewalk or gutter clean and to remove therefrom all materials, snow or ice, trash, weeds, refuse, rubbish or hazards of any kind and to keep the sidewalk and gutter in good repair. If there is no such occupant, it is the duty of the owner to do the same. 
(Code 2000, § 14-114) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipality to regulate and control use of public ways, 11 O.S. § 36-101. 
Sec. 50-22. - Obstructions to passage unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to place upon or permit to be placed upon the sidewalks, parkways, streets and alleys of the city any goods, wares, articles of merchandise or any other obstruction, and leave the same thereon or to use the same as a place to carry on a business or trade, provided, however, the placement of goods, wares and articles of merchandise shall be allowed between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. seven days a week, provided such goods, wares and articles of merchandise do not extend beyond four linear feet from the building line of the business upon which such sidewalk is adjacent thereto. The board of commissioners may, on a case by case basis, by motion, provide for temporary modification of the restrictions hereof, for any city-wide special events. 
(Code 2000, §§ 14-105, 14-106; Ord. No. 679, 12-7-1998) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to prohibit and prevent encroachments and obstructions of streets and sidewalks and to remove them, 11 O.S. § 36-107. 
Sec. 50-23. - Reserved. 
Sec. 50-24. - Unlawful to deposit trash. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deposit, throw or sweep into or upon the streets, alleys, parking or sidewalks of the city any paper, rubbish, grass, weeds, tree trimmings, dirt, trash, crates, boxes or other refuse of any kind. 
(Code 2000, § 14-107) 
State Law reference- Littering of highways and public property prohibited, 21 O.S. § 1753.3. 
Sec. 50-25. - Unlawful to play on sidewalks and in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to play on the sidewalks within the business district or adjacent to any business, in the alleys, or upon the main traveled portions of the streets of the city, except as may be authorized by ordinance. 
(Code 2000, § 14-108; Ord. No. 853, § 1, 4-4-2011) 
Sec. 50-26. - Prohibited use of streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct, erect, place, operate, maintain, or permit to exist any icebox, ice dock, gasoline pump, gasoline storage reservoir, tire rack, tire tools or equipment, water hose connection, or mercantile business, or any tools, stand, equipment, merchandise, or appurtenances thereof, aerials, poles, or wires therefor, whether permanent or temporary, or any other obstruction, upon any part of any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, curbing, parking, or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 14-109) 
Sec. 50-27. - Restriction on vehicle washing. 
    No automobile or other vehicle shall be washed at any place within the city where the water, dirt, mud or other substances removed therefrom by or during the washing thereof shall drain into or upon any street or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 14-110) 
Sec. 50-28. - Outflow from businesses prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any owner or operator of a filling station or other place of business, or any agent or employee thereof, to cause or allow water, grease or other fluid to flow or drain into, upon, over or across any sidewalk, parking, street, alley, sidewalk or other public way. 
(Code 2000, § 14-111) 
Sec. 50-29. - Drainage into sewers not to be obstructed. 
    It is unlawful for any person to obstruct any street, sidewalk, or alley, by placing any approach driveway or other obstruction or substance whatever that will obstruct or prevent the natural flow of water into the storm sewers or drains, or dam the same so as to back any water upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, or gutter. 
(Code 2000, § 14-113) 
Sec. 50-30. - Drainage of polluting substances prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any residence or business to allow drainage of a polluting substance into any street, alley or sidewalk. A polluting substance is one so defined under 82 O.S. § 1084.2. 
(Code 2000, § 14-115) 
Secs. 50-31-50-48. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VIOLATIONS AND ABATEMENT 

Sec. 50-49. - Drainage ditches, obstacles impeding drainage in streets; notice; correction. 
(a)  Any culvert, driveway, pipe, or other obstacle upon or in the dedicated streets, alleys or ways of the city which impedes the flow of water through drainage ditches now constructed or which might hereafter be constructed by the city for the purpose of proper drainage of water falling from any rainfalls which might reasonably be anticipated shall be and are hereby declared to be public nuisances endangering and interfering with travel upon and the repair and maintenance of city streets and annoying, and injuring and endangering the comfort, repose, health and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  All public nuisances existing contrary to the provisions of this section not abated by the owners or occupants of adjoining premises or their agents within ten days after being given notice as provided herein, shall be abated by the mayor or other officer or employee of the city by digging up, breaking, if necessary or not reasonably avoidable, and removing such culvert, driveway, pipe, or other obstacle and opening up such drainage ditch, and leaving the same open. 
(c)  The notice herein mentioned shall be in writing directing the owner or occupant of the premises adjoining such nuisance to abate the same by removing such obstacle impeding drainage and shall be given by mailing to the owner or occupant of such adjoining premises at his or their last known address, or to both, if their names and post office addresses can be ascertained with reasonable diligence, by certified mail or by delivery of such notice to such owner or occupant personally by any officer, employee or agent of the city, or by posting such notice at some conspicuous place upon such premises if the name or mailing address of the owner or occupant of the premises cannot be ascertained with reasonable diligence. 
(Code 2000, § 14-116) 
Sec. 50-50. - Obstacles in street right-of-way; notice; abatement. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to construct, maintain or operate any building, sign, fence, post, gasoline pump, driveway canopy, tree, shrub, or other thing or structure on any right-of-way of or upon any street in the city, and the constructing or maintaining of any such thing or structure on any right-of-way of or upon any such street, shall constitute a public nuisance, which may be summarily abated by the city or its officers, agents, servants and employees in the manner provided in this section. 
(b)  If the owner or person in possession of any building, sign, fence, post, gasoline pump, driveway canopy, tree, shrub, or other thing or structure on any right-of-way of or upon any street fails to remove such structure or thing by ten days after written demand for the removal thereof has been made upon him by registered mail or personal service, the city, its officers, agents, servants and employees are hereby authorized and empowered to physically tear down and remove such thing or structure, and for such purposes may enter upon private property to the extent necessary to accomplish such removal. Neither the city nor its officers, agents, servants or employees shall be liable for any damage caused or sustained by reason of the abatement and removal of such nuisance. 
(c)  This section is not intended to prevent the construction or maintenance of any culvert or driveway as a means of ingress and egress to private property. The city shall have power to regulate the construction and maintenance of such culverts or driveways with due regard to the safety of the traveling public, and also drainage and maintenance of the streets. 
(d)  The police department may abate any such nuisance as is described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 14-117) 
Secs. 50-51-50-73. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-74. - Owner or occupant not to permit sidewalk or sidewalk area to become a hazard. 
    It is unlawful for the owner or occupant of property abutting upon a sidewalk area to permit the sidewalk or sidewalk area adjacent to the property to become a hazard to persons using the sidewalk or sidewalk area. 
(Code 2000, § 14-112) 
Sec. 50-75. - Injury to sidewalk. 
    It is unlawful and an offense for any person to cut, carve, strike, paint, bore, dig or otherwise commit any injury or damage to any sidewalk now existing or hereafter constructed within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 14-210) 
Sec. 50-76. - Sidewalk cutting; bond; permission criteria. 
(a)  In any case when it is necessary for any person, in the pursuit of a lawful object and the same becomes necessary, to cut, bore, dig, excavate or remove any sidewalk or part thereof, the same shall be allowed by first obtaining the consent of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  In order to cut, bore, dig, excavate or remove any sidewalk, a person shall file a bond, conditioned that such cutting or injury shall be done and all work in connection with same without delay, that proper safeguards shall be erected and maintained during all such construction, and such sidewalk will be immediately repaired and restored to a condition of public safety, conformable in all respects to its former condition. The bond shall further bind the party to pay any and all damages arising out of the cutting, excavation, guarding and reconstruction which may accrue therefrom and that such party shall hold the city harmless at all events. 
(c)  A written permit shall be issued by the city clerk, naming the place, parties and conditions of use and shall state a time within which such work shall be entirely completed and the walk restored to its former condition of use. The application for permit shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2000, § 14-211) 
Secs. 50-77-50-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 50-96. - Permit required; fees. 
(a)  All sidewalk construction and repair on any street, avenue or alley in the city shall be done subject to and strictly in all respects conform to all provisions set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall build, construct or repair any sidewalk on any street, avenue or alley in the city without first having obtained a written permit from the city clerk. The permit shall show the name of the property owner, the contractor or person who is to do the work and the lot and block numbers on which the work is to be done, and in addition the part of the city in which it is located, the same being cited by reference to the original town site or addition by name. 
(c)  The application for permit under this section shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2000, § 14-201) 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to make sidewalk improvements, 11 O.S. § 36-401. 
Sec. 50-97. - Conditions for permit. 
    All permits issued for sidewalk construction or repair shall be issued on the condition that the work will be done strictly in accord with the city ordinances relating to the same, and all persons having any part or interest in any sidewalk construction or repair are charged with and bound by the provisions of this article, notwithstanding the same may not be specially set forth in the permit. 
(Code 2000, § 14-202) 
Sec. 50-98. - Inspection. 
    All sidewalk construction and repair work shall be done under the direct supervision of the building official. It shall be his duty when any construction or repair work has been completely finished in accordance with the ordinances relating to the same to issue a certificate of approval, a copy of which shall be filed with the city clerk. A copy of the certificate shall be given to the contractor and a copy of the same to the owner of the property. No right of action for work done or labor or materials supplied on any contract for sidewalk construction or repair work shall arise nor shall any materialman's or laborer's lien be held to be established until the inspector has approved the work and issued and delivered his certificate. The certificate herein mentioned shall be issued only after the completion of the work and shall certify that the work and materials in all respects comply with the city ordinances. 
(Code 2000, § 14-203) 
Sec. 50-99. - Material used. 
    Sidewalks constructed in any street, avenue, alley or public ground in the city shall be constructed either of concrete or other material subject to the approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 2000, § 14-204) 
Sec. 50-100. - Specifications. 
    All sidewalks shall be built by the specifications adopted by the city and none other. 
(Code 2000, § 14-205) 
Sec. 50-101. - Repair standards. 
    All sidewalks out of repair shall be repaired with good material of the same kind and dimensions and of quality equal to that originally used in the construction of the sidewalk, and well laid so as to correspond with the rest of the sidewalk. Any sidewalks or parts thereof which have settled so as to make depressions or have become raised above the grade of the sidewalk shall be replaced on the same grade as the rest of the walk. 
(Code 2000, § 14-206) 
Sec. 50-102. - Condemnation. 
    The board of commissioners may at any time by resolution condemn any portion of sidewalk whenever in their judgment it shall be deemed necessary for the public safety and provide for the construction of a new sidewalk in accordance with this and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 14-207) 
Sec. 50-103. - Sidewalk widths in business area. 
    The sidewalks in the business area within the city on Main Street and Broadway shall be constructed in the manner established by the city planning commission or city commission and approved by the city commission through motion, resolution or ordinance. 
(Code 2000, § 14-208; Ord. No. 832, § 1, 5-18-2009) 
Sec. 50-104. - Distance from property line. 
    All distances of the sidewalk from the property line shall be as provided in section 50-100. 
(Code 2000, § 14-209) 
Secs. 50-105-50-121. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 50-122. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bore means a crossing made in such a manner so as not to disturb the surface covering, i.e., asphalt, concrete, brick, gravel, oil matte and chip or dirt. 
    Contractor means any person engaged in the business of installing or replacing lines, pipes or cables for a property owner or utility. 
    Opening means a crossing which cuts or otherwise disturbs the surface covering. 
    Utility means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the supply of water, gas, electric, telephone or cable TV service. 
(Code 2000, § 14-301; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Sec. 50-123. - Cutting pavement. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to cut, open up, excavate, bore or dig into any pavement or paved street within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk, which shall be approved by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Before any such permit is granted, the person shall bind himself to open up only so much as may be necessary for the declared purposes, to properly and effectively erect and maintain all guards from danger, to close up without delay, and to perform all such duties and work within a reasonable time without any delay and to repair and restore such pavement in its original good condition. 
(c)  Applications for permits under this section shall be accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2000, § 14-102) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to regulate street excavations, 11 O.S. § 36-107. 
Sec. 50-124. - Street crossings. 
(a)  Permit required to make road bore. Any utility or contractor required to make a street crossing shall accomplish same by making a road bore. An application for a crossing permit must be made as set forth in this chapter. No fee will be assessed for bored street crossings. 
(b)  Procedure to be followed to make street opening. In the event rock, local terrain or other circumstances prohibit boring, the utility or contractor may be permitted to make the opening in the following manner for: 
(1)  Streets other than brick. The initial cut of the surface covering must be made with a concrete saw or other similar equipment to accomplish an even cut of the roadway material. The opened area may then be dug out with a trencher or other similar equipment. The backfill shall be tamped at not less than six-inch intervals to alleviate undue settling. Following backfill, the surface covering shall be repaired to the same as or better than the original condition. Like type and quality material shall be used to accomplish a smooth and even surface. 
(2)  Brick streets. The crossing shall be accomplished by removing brick from the required area and trenching the crossing. The backfill shall be tamped not less than six-inch intervals to alleviate undue settling. Following backfill, the brick shall be replaced in the original pattern in a smooth and even manner. 
(c)  Permit fee. An application for crossing permit must be made as set forth herein, accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2000, § 14-302; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Sec. 50-125. - Alley crossings. 
(a)  Any utility or contractor required to make an alley crossing may do so by cutting the surface covering with a trencher or other similar equipment to accomplish an even cut of the alleyway material. The backfill shall be tamped at not less than six-inch intervals to alleviate undue settling. Following backfill, surface covering shall be repaired to the same as or better than original condition. Like type and quality material shall be used to accomplish a smooth and even surface. 
(b)  An application for an alley crossing permit must be made as set forth herein, accompanied by a permit fee in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 2000, § 14-303; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Sec. 50-126. - Utility or contractor's liability. 
(a)  The utility or contractor shall notify city hall upon completion of the crossing (either bored or opened). 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the utility or contractor to maintain the crossing area for a period of 90 days following notification of completion of the crossing. 
(c)  The city shall make periodic inspections of the crossing and shall notify the utility or contractor if maintenance is required. Notification shall be made by first class mail to the address provided by the utility or contractor. 
(d)  The utility or contractor shall have ten business days in which to complete any maintenance required under this section. If, due to inclement weather, an extension is necessary, the utility or contractor may apply for same prior to the expiration of time allowed for the completion of work. 
(Code 2000, § 14-304; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Sec. 50-127. - Work to be completed. 
    Any street or alley opened under this article shall be repaired to a passable condition within five working days of the issuance of the permit for same. If, due to inclement weather, an extension is necessary, the application for same may be applied for prior to the expiration of the permit. 
(Code 2000, § 14-306; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Sec. 50-128. - Location of utilities. 
    It is the responsibility of the utility or contractor to arrange for the locating of all utilities in the area. Water, sewer and electric line will be located free of charge by the city upon 48 hours' notice to city hall. The utility or contractor shall be liable for any damage to utilities for which location has not been requested. 
(Code 2000, § 14-307; Ord. No. 531, 3-4-1985) 
Secs. 50-129-50-154. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STREET NAMES AND STRUCTURE NUMBERING 

Sec. 50-155. - Attachment of numbers required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use any numbers except those assigned and designated by the city. It is the duty of all persons owning, residing in or occupying or using any building or house to place a number thereon in a conspicuous place at the front in accordance with the number required. 
(Code 2000, § 5-701; Ord. No. 466, 12-10-1979) 
Sec. 50-156. - North and south streets. 
    All streets within the city running in a north and south direction shall be named, designated and known by a number, the number being determined as follows: The first street adjacent to the eastern boundary within the city shall be known as Fifth Street and each street paralleling the same on the west side shall be known by a number, the same being ascertained by increasing the number of the next succeeding street by one. The streets shall be known as Fifth, Sixth, Seventh, etc., without excepting any street, continuously and uninterruptedly across the city to the western boundary. 
(Code 2000, § 5-702) 
Sec. 50-157. - East and west streets. 
    All streets within the city running in an east and west direction shall continue with the names and designations as they existed at the time of the adoption of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 5-703) 
Sec. 50-158. - Lot and block designation. 
(a)  For the purpose of locating and designating the house and lots of the city by a uniform system, all blocks shall bear two designations, to include a number and a direction. All blocks shall be numbered in arithmetic series with 100 as the common difference, and beginning with 100 as the number of the first block, each block increasing regularly by the common difference until the last block is reached. 
(b)  All measurements shall begin, for north and south measurements from Main Street and all measurements for east and west measurements shall begin from Fifth Street. The terms "North" and "South" shall be added to each block respectively as it lies north or south of Main Street to designate its direction from Main Street. The terms "East" and "West" shall be added to each block respectively as it lies east or west of Fifth Street to designate its direction from Fifth Street. 
(Code 2000, § 5-704) 
Sec. 50-159. - Lot numbers. 
    For the purpose of numbering each lot within a block, the lots shall be of uniform size of 25 feet frontage on the street. The number of each lot shall be determined by beginning at the corner nearest the baseline and continuing the numbering of each consecutive lot in the block, to which shall be added the block number in each case, including the block designation. Whole number or unit numbers shall be used for fractional adjoining lots. Numbers shall begin with the smallest whole number, one or two as the case may be, and increased without interruption and consecutively until the last lot in the respective block; provided that even numbers only shall be used for lots fronting south or east and odd numbers only shall be used for lots fronting north or west. 
(Code 2000, § 5-705) 
Sec. 50-160. - Baselines. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, Main Street is hereby designated as the baseline for numbering and designating lots and blocks fronting on streets running north and south and Fifth Street is hereby designated as the baseline for numbering and designating lots and blocks fronting on streets running east and west. 
(Code 2000, § 5-706) 
Sec. 50-161. - Naming of streets. 
    The names of any streets opened up or established shall be designated by the city clerk in conformity with the existing street-naming system. The names of existing streets shall be changed only by ordinance. However, whenever any territory is annexed to the city, the city clerk shall change any names of streets in the territory so annexed that do not conform to the existing street-naming system and such change shall become effective upon the city clerk notifying the board of commissioners. 
(Code 2000, § 5-707) 
Sec. 50-162. - Maps and records. 
    The city clerk shall maintain an official map and record of all street, building and house numbers so assigned, and showing all of the officially designated names of streets, which maps and records shall be open to public use. 
(Code 2000, § 5-708) 
Sec. 50-163. - Penalty. 
    Any person who uses any house or building number other than the official number required by this Code or who refuses to use or attach the number required to the front of such house or building ten days after written notice from the city clerk shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 2000, § 5-709; Ord. No. 466, 12-10-1979)

Chapter 54 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation generally, 68 O.S. § 2701 et seq.; Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.; Streamlined Sales Tax System Act, 68 O.S. § 1354.7 et seq.; Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Administration Act, 68 O.S. § 1354.14 et seq.; uniform tax procedure, 68 O.S. § 201 et seq.; Franchise Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1201 et seq.; Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq.; municipal tax on utilities, 68 O.S. § 2601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 54-1-54-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SALES TAXES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 54-19. - Definitions. 
    The definitions of words, terms and phrases contained in 68 O.S. § 1352 and 37 O.S. § 576 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-202) 
State Law reference- Definitions related to sales taxation, 68 O.S. § 1352; definition related to gross receipts tax on certain alcoholic beverage license holders, 37 O.S. § 576. 
Sec. 54-20. - Tax collector defined. 
    The term "tax collector" as used in this article, means the department of the city or the official agency of the state duly designated according to law or contract, and authorized by law to administer the collection of the tax levied in this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-203) 
Sec. 54-21. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    For the purpose of this article, the classification of taxpayers hereunder shall be as prescribed by state law for purposes of the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 7-204) 
Sec. 54-22. - Subsisting state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the state tax commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., are, for the purpose of this article, hereby ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Code 2000, § 7-205) 
Sec. 54-23. - Effective date. 
    This article became effective as to each cent tax at least 30 days after approval of a majority of the registered voters of the city voting on the ordinance in the manner prescribed by 11 O.S. § 16-112. 
(Code 2000, § 7-206) 
Sec. 54-24. - Purpose of revenues. 
    It is the purpose of the sales tax levied by this article to provide revenues for the support of the functions of the municipal government of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-207) 
Sec. 54-25. - Levy of tax rate; sales subject to tax; exemptions. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an excise tax of 3.75 percent upon the gross proceeds or gross receipts derived from all sales taxable under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., including, but not by way of limitation, those sales enumerated in 68 O.S. § 1354, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  There is hereby executed from the tax imposed in this section all sales exemption under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., including, but not by way of limitation, those sales enumerated in 68 O.S. § 1355 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
(Code 2000, § 7-208; Ord. No. 373, eff. 3-1-1967; Ord. No. 442, eff. 7-1-1977; Ord. No. 684, eff. 5-17-1999; Ord. No. 826, 1-5-2009) 
Editor's note- Ordinance Number 373, became effective March 1, 1967, levying a first ($0.01) tax. Ordinance Number 442, effective July 1, 1977, levied the second one cent ($0.01) tax. Ordinance Number 684, effective May 17, 1999, levied the third one cent ($0.01) tax. Ordinance Number 826, effective July 1, 2009, levied an additional 3/4 percent. 
Secs. 54-26-54-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - COLLECTION OF TAXES 

Sec. 54-54. - When tax due; returns; records. 
    The tax levied hereunder shall be due and payable at the time and in the manner and form prescribed for payment of the state sales tax under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 7-215) 
Sec. 54-55. - Payment of tax; brackets. 
(a)  The tax herein levied shall be paid to the tax collector at the time and in the form and manner provided for payment of state sales tax. 
(b)  The bracket system for the collection of the city sales tax by the tax collector shall be the same as is hereafter adopted by the agreement of the city and the tax collector, in the collection of both the city sales tax and the 4.5 percent state sales tax provided for in 68 O.S. § 1354. 
(Code 2000, § 7-216) 
Sec. 54-56. - Tax constitutes debt. 
    The taxes, penalty and interest due under this article shall at all times constitute a prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured creditors, and may be collected by suit as any other debt. 
(Code 2000, § 7-217) 
Sec. 54-57. - Vendor's duty to collect tax; penalties. 
(a)  The tax levied hereunder shall be paid by the consumer or user to the vendor. It shall be the duty of each and every vendor in this city to collect from the consumer or user the full amount of the tax levied by this article, or an amount equal as nearly as possible or practicable to the average equivalent thereof. 
(b)  Vendors shall add the tax imposed hereunder, or the average equivalent thereof, to the sales price or charge, and when added such tax shall constitute a part of such price or charge, shall be a debt from the consumer or user to vendor until paid, and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. 
(c)  A vendor, as defined hereunder, who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to collect the full amount of the tax levied by this article, or willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions, or remits or rebates to a consumer or user either directly or indirectly and by whatsoever means all or any part of the tax herein levied, or makes in any form of advertising, verbally or otherwise, any statement which infers that he is absorbing the tax, or paying the tax for the consumer or user by an adjustment of prices or at a price including the tax, or in any manner whatsoever, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined as provided in section 1-11. 
(d)  Any sum or sums collected or required to be collected in accordance with this article shall be deemed to be held in trust for the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-218) 
Sec. 54-58. - Returns and remittances; discounts. 
    Returns and remittances of the tax herein levied and collected shall be made to the tax collector at the time and in the manner, form and amount as prescribed for returns and remittances of tax collected hereunder and shall be subject to the same discount as may be allowed by the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq., for collection of state sales taxes. 
(Code 2000, § 7-219) 
Sec. 54-59. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    Vendors shall be classified in the manner provided for classification of taxpayers in the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1350 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 7-220) 
Sec. 54-60. - Interest and penalties; delinquency. 
    The city adopts and incorporates herein 68 O.S. § 217, and interest and penalties at the rates and in amounts as therein specified are hereby levied and shall be applicable in cases of delinquency in reporting and paying the tax levied by this article. The failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make and transmit the reports and remittances of tax in the time and manner required by this article shall cause such tax to be delinquent. In addition, if the delinquency continues for a period of five days, the taxpayer shall forfeit his claim to any discount allowed under this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-221) 
Sec. 54-61. - Waiver of interest and penalties. 
    The interest or penalty or any portion thereof accruing by reason of a taxpayer's failure to pay the city tax herein levied may be waived or remitted in the same manner as provided for the waiver or as applied in administration of the state sales tax provided in 68 O.S. § 220, which section is adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-222) 
Sec. 54-62. - Erroneous payments; claim for refund. 
    Refund of erroneous payment of the city sales tax herein levied may be made to any taxpayer making the erroneous payment in the same manner and procedure, and under the same limitations of time, as provided for administration of the state sales tax as set forth in 68 O.S. § 227, which section is adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-223) 
Sec. 54-63. - Fraudulent returns. 
    It is unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to make reports and remittances herein required, or to make a false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-224) 
Sec. 54-64. - Records confidential. 
    The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the administration of the city sales tax is legislatively recognized and declared, and to protect the same the provisions of the 68 O.S. § 205 and each subsection thereof, are hereby adopted by reference and made fully effective and applicable to administration of the city sales tax as if here set forth in full. 
(Code 2000, § 7-225) 
Sec. 54-65. - Amendments. 
    The people of the city, by their approval of the sales tax ordinance, hereby authorize the city board of commissioners, by ordinance duly enacted, to make such administrative and technical changes or additions in the method and manner of administering and enforcing this article as may be necessary or proper for efficiency and fairness. Neither the rate of the tax herein provided nor the use to which the revenue is put shall be changed without approval of the qualified electors of the city as provided by law. 
(Code 2000, § 7-226) 
Sec. 54-66. - Provisions cumulative. 
    The provisions of this article shall be cumulative and in addition to any or all other taxing provisions of this Code or other city ordinances. 
(Code 2000, § 7-227) 
Secs. 54-67-54-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - USE TAX 

Sec. 54-91. - Definitions. 
    The definitions of words, terms and phrases contained in the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq., are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. In addition thereto, the following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Tax collector means the department of the city government or the official agency of the state duly designated according to law, or contract authorized by law, to administer the collection of the tax herein levied. 
    Transaction means sale. 
(Code 2000, § 7-302; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-92. - Excise tax levied; exemptions. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and there shall be paid by every person storing, using or otherwise consuming within the city tangible, personal property purchased or brought into this city, an excise tax on the storage, use or otherwise consuming within in the city of such property at the rate of 33/4 percent of the purchase price of such property. 
(b)  Such tax shall be paid by every person storing, using or otherwise consuming, within the city, tangible, personal property purchased or brought into the city. 
(c)  The additional tax levied hereunder shall be paid at the time of importation or storage of the property within the city and shall be assessed only to property purchased outside the state; provided, that the tax levied herein shall not be levied against tangible, personal property intended solely for use outside the city, but which is stored in the city pending shipment outside the city or which is temporarily retained in the city for the purpose of fabrication, repair, testing, alteration, maintenance or other service. 
(d)  Any person liable for payment of the tax authorized herein, may deduct from such tax any local or municipal sales tax previously paid on such goods or services; provided, that the amount deducted shall not exceed the amount that would have been due if the taxes imposed by the city had been levied on the sale of such goods or services. 
(e)  The tax levied in this section shall not apply to those uses exempted pursuant to 68 O.S. § 1404. 
(Code 2000, § 7-303; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991; Ord. No. 687, 10-4-1999; Ord. No. 829, § 1, 4-13-2009) 
Sec. 54-93. - Purpose of revenues. 
    It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article to provide revenues for support of the functions of the municipal government of the city, and any and all revenues derived hereunder may be expended by the governing body of the city for any purpose for which funds may be lawfully expended as authorized. 
(Code 2000, § 7-304; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-94. - When due; returns; payment. 
    The tax levied by this article is due and payable at the time and in the manner and form prescribed for payment of the state use tax under the use tax code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 7-306; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-95. - Tax constitutes debt. 
    Such taxes, penalty and interest due hereunder shall at all times constitute a prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured creditors, and may be collected by suit as any other debt. 
(Code 2000, § 7-307; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-96. - Collection of tax by retailer or vendor. 
    Every retailer or vendor maintaining places of business both within and without the state, and making sales of tangible, personal property from a place of business outside this state for use in this city shall at the time of making such sales collect the use tax levied by this article from the purchaser and give to the purchaser a receipt therefor in the manner and form prescribed by the tax commission, if the tax commission shall, by regulation, require such receipt. Each retailer or vendor shall list with the tax commission the name and address of all his agents operating in this city and location of any and all distribution or sales houses or offices or other places of business in the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-308; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-97. - Collection of tax by retailer or vendor; permits. 
(a)  The tax commission may, in its discretion, upon application, authorize the collection of the tax herein levied by: 
(1)  Any retailer or vendor not maintaining a place of business within this state but who makes sales of tangible, personal property for use in this city, and 
(2)  By the out-of-state places of business of any retailer or vendor maintaining places of business both within and without this state and making sales of tangible, personal property such out-of-state place of business for use in this city. Such retailer or vendor may be issued, without charge, a permit to collect such taxes by the tax commission in such manner and subject to such regulations and agreements as it shall prescribe. 
(b)  When so authorized, it shall be the duty of such retailer or vendor to collect the tax upon all tangible, personal property sold to his knowledge for use within this city. Such authority and permit may be cancelled when at any time the tax commission considers that such tax can more effectively be collected from the person using such property in this city; provided, however, that in all instances where such sales are made or completed by delivery to the purchaser within this city by the retailer or vendor in such retailer's or vendor's vehicle, whether owned or leased (not by common carrier), such sales or transactions shall continue to be subject to applicable city sales tax at the point of delivery and the tax shall be collected and reported under taxpayer's sales tax permit number accordingly. 
(Code 2000, § 7-309; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-98. - Revoking permits. 
    Whenever any retailer or vendor not maintaining a place of business in this state, or both within and without this state, and authorized to collect the tax herein levied, fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article or the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq., or any orders, rules or regulations of the tax commission, the tax commission may, upon notice and hearing as provided for in 68 O.S. § 1408, by order revoke the use tax permit, if any, issued to such retailer or vendor, and if any such retailer or vendor is a corporation authorized to do business in this state may, after notice and hearing above provided, cancel the corporation's license to do business in this state and shall issue a new license only when such corporation has complied with the obligations under this article, the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq., or any orders, rules or regulations of the tax commission. 
(Code 2000, § 7-310; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-99. - Remunerative deductions allowed vendors or retailers of other states. 
    Returns and remittances of the tax herein levied and collected shall be made to the tax commission at the time and in the manner, form and amount as prescribed for returns and remittances required by the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq.; and remittances of the tax collected hereunder shall be subject to the same discount as may be allowed by the code for the collection of state use taxes. 
(Code 2000, § 7-311; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-100. - Interest and penalties; delinquency. 
    The city adopts and makes a part of this article 68 O.S. § 217, and interest and penalties at the rates and in the amounts as herein specified are hereby levied and shall be applicable in cases of delinquency in reporting and paying the tax levied by this article; provided, that the failure or refusal of any retailer or vendor to make and transmit the reports and remittances of tax in the time and manner required by this article shall cause such tax to be delinquent. In addition, if such delinquency continues for a period of five days, the retailer or vendor shall forfeit his claim to any discount allowed under this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-312; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-101. - Waiver of interest and penalties. 
    The interest or penalty or any portion thereof accruing by reason of a retailer's or vendor's failure to pay the city tax herein levied may be waived or remitted in the same manner as provided for the waiver or remittance as applied in administration of the state use tax provided in 68 O.S. § 227, and to accomplish the purposes of this section the applicable provisions of 68 O.S. § 227 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-313; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-102. - Erroneous payments; claim for refund. 
    Refund of erroneous payment of the city use tax herein levied may be made to any taxpayer making such erroneous payment in the same manner and procedure, and under the same limitations of time, as provided for administration of the state use tax as set forth in 68 O.S. § 227, and to accomplish the purpose of this section, the applicable provisions of 68 O.S. § 227 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-314; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-103. - Fraudulent returns. 
    It is unlawful for any person to willfully fail or refuse to make reports and remittances herein required, or to make any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-315; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-104. - Records confidential. 
    The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the administration of the city use tax is legislatively recognized and declared, and to protect the same the provisions of 68 O.S. § 205, of the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, and each subsection thereof, is hereby adopted by reference and made fully effective and applicable to administration of the city use tax as is herein set forth in full. 
(Code 2000, § 7-316; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-105. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    For the purpose of this article, the classification of taxpayers hereunder shall be as prescribed by state law for purposes of the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 7-317; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-106. - Subsisting state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the tax commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Use Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 1401 et seq. are for the purpose of this article hereby ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Code 2000, § 7-318; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Sec. 54-107. - Provisions cumulative. 
    The provisions hereof shall be cumulative, and in addition to any and all other taxing provisions of the city ordinances. 
(Code 2000, § 7-319; Ord. No. 609, 10-21-1991) 
Secs. 54-108-54-127. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - UTILITY TAX 

Sec. 54-128. - Utility tax levied on gross receipts. 
    Pursuant to 68 O.S. §§ 2601 through 2605, there is hereby levied and assessed an annual tax upon the gross receipts from residential and commercial sales of power, light, heat, gas, electricity and water, communication services and other utilities within the city limits in an amount of two percent of the gross receipts from residential and commercial sales, which tax shall be in lieu of any other franchise, license, occupation or excise tax, levied by the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-401; Ord. No. 488, 1-12-1981; Ord. No. 766, § 1, 6-13-2005) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy gross receipts tax, 68 O.S. § 2601 et seq. 
Sec. 54-129. - Application; utilities operating under franchise and sales by city excepted. 
    The tax authorized to be levied under this article shall be levied at the time the ordinance from which this article is derived shall take effect and shall apply to all persons engaged in the business of furnishing power, light, heat, gas, electricity and water, communication systems and other utilities in the city, except it shall not apply to any person operating under a valid franchise from the city or to sales of electricity or water made by the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-402; Ord. No. 488, 1-12-1981; Ord. No. 766, § 1, 6-13-2005) 
Sec. 54-130. - Payments and statements due quarterly. 
    The annual tax levied under this article shall be payable monthly beginning with the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived and placed in the general revenue fund of the city. Every person subject to the provisions hereof shall with each monthly payment furnish a complete and accurate verified statement of all gross receipts from residential and commercial sales within the city during the period for which the monthly payment is made. The statement and payment shall be made to the city clerk not more than 15 days after the expiration of the month when due. 
(Code 2000, § 7-403; Ord. No. 766, § 1, 6-13-2005) 
Sec. 54-131. - Penalty. 
    Any person failing or refusing to pay such tax shall be regarded as a trespasser and may be ousted from the city, and in addition thereto an action may be maintained against such person for the amount of the tax and all expense of collecting the same, including reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Code 2000, § 7-404) 
Sec. 54-132. - Lien. 
    The tax imposed hereunder shall constitute a first and prior lien upon all of the assets located within the city of any person engaged in the business of selling power, light, heat, gas or electricity therein. 
(Code 2000, § 7-405) 
Secs. 54-133-54-162. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TELEPHONE TAXES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 54-163-54-192. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TELEPHONE EXCHANGE FEE 

Sec. 54-193. - Telephone exchange fee levied. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an annual inspection fee and service charge upon each and every person, firm and corporation operating a telephone exchange in the city in an amount equal to two percent of the gross revenues for each current year for exchange telephone transmission service rendered wholly within the limits of the city to compensate the city for the expense incurred and services rendered incident to the exercise of its police power, supervision, police regulation and police control of the construction of lines and equipment of the telephone company in the city. 
(b)  The inspection fee and charge shall be due and payable to the city on or before January 1 of each year, and shall be paid into the general revenue fund of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-501) 
Sec. 54-194. - Fee in lieu of franchise fee. 
    During continued substantial compliance with the terms of this article by the owner of any telephone exchange, the charge levied hereby shall be and continue to be in lieu of all concessions, charges, excise, franchise, license, privilege and permit fees or taxes or assessments except ad valorem taxes. However, it is not intended hereby to extinguish or abrogate any existing arrangement whereby the city is permitted to use underground conduit, duct space or pole contacts of the company for the fire alarm and/or police call systems of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-502) 
Secs. 54-195-54-211. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EMERGENCY TELEPHONE TAX 

Sec. 54-212. - Definitions. 
    Words and phrases used in this article shall have the definitions set forth in 63 O.S. § 2813, where the phrase or word is defined in such statute. 
(Code 2000, § 7-601; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-213. - Tax on telephone tariff. 
    There is hereby imposed upon the tariff charges for exchange telephone service or its equivalent of the local exchange telephone company providing service within the corporate limits of the city a fee of five percent. Three percent of the proceeds of the fee shall be utilized to pay for the operation of emergency telephone service as defined in 63 O.S. § 2813. Two percent of the proceeds of the fee shall be utilized for the purchase of ancillary communication systems necessary to pass the reported emergency to the appropriate emergency service and personnel. Such two percent fee shall remain in effect for such time as the board of commissioners of the city deem necessary for the purposes aforestated. 
(Code 2000, § 7-602; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988; Ord. No. 635) 
Sec. 54-214. - Limitation. 
    No such fee shall be imposed upon more than 100 exchange access lines or their equivalent at one location per service user. 
(Code 2000, § 7-603; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-215. - Collection. 
    The fee shall be collected monthly by the local exchange telephone company and forwarded 30 days of the close of the month in which such fee was collected to the city clerk of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-604; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-216. - Use of funds. 
    Revenues derived from the fee hereby imposed shall be utilized for engineering, installation, administration and other recurring and one-time costs necessary to implement, administer, operate and maintain emergency 911 telephone service in the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-605; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-217. - Administration of service. 
    The chief of police, or any other official designated by the city commission, is authorized to administer the 911 telephone service within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-606; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-218. - Cooperation with other agencies. 
    The chief of police or other person charged with administration of the emergency telephone service is authorized to cooperate with other governing bodies who may impose a similar fee and who wish to participate in a regional 911 service. 
(Code 2000, § 7-607; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-219. - Administrative fee. 
    The local exchange telephone company providing service within the city shall be entitled to retain as an administrative fee three percent of the fee imposed and collected pursuant to this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-608; Ord. No. 566, 5-2-1988) 
Sec. 54-220. - E-911 fund created. 
    There is hereby created an E-911 fund account that shall be separate and apart from other accounts of the city. The board of commissioners shall make such appropriations and appropriate into the fund as necessary. All purchases and disbursements from the E-911 fund shall be in accordance with the ordinances of the city and state law. 
(Code 2000, § 7-609; Ord. No. 701, 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 54-221. - Voice over internet protocol (VOIP) telephone service fee. 
    The board of commissioners has approved the acquisition and operation of an emergency telephone service and pursuant to the 911 Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) Emergency Service Act, 63 O.S. § 2851, does hereby impose and adopt a 911 service fee upon interconnected voice over internet protocol telephone service customers whose businesses or residences are located within the city limits at the rate amount as provided in the city fee schedule, per month, for each VOIP service user. All VOIP carriers having customers within the city shall provide an annual census of customers to the city no later than 60 days after the first day of each calendar year. The fee shall be collected by all VOIP carriers having customers within the city and forwarded to the city clerk within 30 days of the month in which such fee was collected. 
(Ord. No. 841, § 1, 11-12-2009) 
Secs. 54-222-54-248. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAX REBATE FOR SENIOR CITIZENS 

Sec. 54-249. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dependent means every person who is a member of the household of the applicant and for whom the applicant is entitled to claim a personal exemption under and pursuant to the federal income tax laws. 
    Family means one or more persons living in the same household who pool their various sources of income into one budget to achieve the effect of sharing the cost of providing for support of the group. 
    Household includes all persons who occupy a group of rooms or single room which is regarded as a housing unit when it is occupied as separate living quarters, and when there is either direct access from the outside of the building or through a common hall or complete kitchen facilities for the exclusive use of the occupants. 
    Income includes all money received during the year and available to be used to provide support for the family or household. 
    Person means an individual, but shall not include a company, partnership, joint venture, joint agreement, association (mutual or otherwise), corporation, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, or trustee appointed by state or federal court or otherwise, syndicate, the state, any court, city, municipality, school district, or any other political subdivision of the state, or group or combination acting as a unit, in the plural or singular number. 
    Resident means any person who has resided in the corporate limits of the city for the entire calendar year for which the refund is applied. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 1, 7-1-2009) 
Sec. 54-250. - Qualifications for rebate. 
    Every person desiring to make a claim for a tax rebate must submit to the city a written application therefor, on forms to be provided by the city, between January 1 and March 31 of the year following the year for which the rebate is being sought, beginning with the year 2010. The qualifications for rebate include the following: 
(1)  The person must be a resident of the city. 
(2)  The person must be 65 years of age or older during a portion of the year for which the rebate is being sought. 
(3)  The person can claim a rebate only as a family member who contributed the greatest share of the family income and for members of the household who are residents of the city and who are dependent upon the said applicant. 
(4)  No person who may be claimed as a member of the household on another resident's application shall be entitled to a rebate. If a rebate is claimed on more than one application for the same person, the city treasurer shall determine the person entitled to claim the rebate provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 2, 7-1-2009) 
Sec. 54-251. - Amount of rebate. 
    If the applicant meets the requirements to qualify for a rebate, the city shall rebate the sum of $25.00. The amount of rebate provided in this section shall apply to each year of the 20-year program. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 3, 7-1-2009) 
Sec. 54-252. - Administration; rules and regulations; application form. 
    The city treasurer is to administer the rebate program established in this article. The city treasurer is authorized to prepare a form for application for rebate and adopt rules and regulations as long as the same are not inconsistent with the provisions of this article, and shall audit and check the applications. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 4, 7-1-2009) 
Sec. 54-253. - Applicant to establish qualifications; supporting information. 
(a)  The burden is on the applicant to establish entitlement to a rebate. 
(b)  The city treasurer is authorized to require reasonable supporting information which shall be uniformly required of all applicants. Upon an audit of the application, the city treasurer can require all reasonable written and other information necessary to the city treasurer's satisfaction that the application is valid. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 5, 7-1-2009) 
Sec. 54-254. - Denial of application; request for hearing; review by board of commissioners. 
(a)  Should any application be denied, the city treasurer shall state the reasons therefor in writing to the applicant and indicate all or the portion of the application being denied. 
(b)  The city treasurer's determination shall be final unless the applicant, within 30 days after such notice of determination, shall apply in writing to the city for a hearing. After such hearing, the board of commissioners shall give written notice of the determination to the applicant. 
(c)  An applicant shall not be entitled to a rebate when he has been denied by the board of commissioners or when he has had an opportunity for a hearing as provided in this article and has failed to avail himself of the remedies herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 828, § 5, 7-1-2009) 
Chapter 56 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform Vehicle Code, 47 O.S. § 1-101 et seq.; driver's licenses, 47 O.S. § 6-101 et seq.; accidents and accident reports, 47 O.S. § 10-101 et seq.; rules of the road, 47 O.S. § 11-101 et seq.; traffic signs, signals, and markings, 47 O.S. § 11-201 et seq.; pedestrian rights and duties, 47 O.S. § 11-501 et seq.; speed restrictions, 47 O.S. § 11-801 et seq.; reckless driving and driving while intoxicated, 47 O.S. § 11-901 et seq.; stopping, standing and parking, 47 O.S. § 11-1001 et seq.; operation of bicycles and play vehicles, 47 O.S. § 11-1201 et seq.; vehicle equipment, 47 O.S. § 12-101 et seq.; vehicle inspection, 47 O.S. § 13-101 et seq.; size, weight, and load regulations, 47 O.S. § 14-101 et seq.; Oklahoma Vehicle Excise Tax Code, 68 O.S. § 2101 et seq.; railroads generally, 66 O.S. § 1 et seq.; authority for municipal traffic ordinances and regulations and for designation of school zone speed limits, 11 O.S. § 22-117; municipal authority to regulate taxicabs, 11 O.S. § 22-118; municipal regulation of railway and freight operations within municipal limits, 11 O.S. § 22-119; municipal authority for regulation of roads and streets, 11 O.S. § 36-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 56-1. - Adoption of state traffic code. 
    The provisions of the state highway safety code, 47 O.S. § 1-101 et seq., including the rules of the road, 47 O.S. § 11-101 et seq., are hereby adopted and incorporated herein by reference to the extent applicable, and are enforceable by the city within the city limits as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 2000, § 15-104; Ord. No. 568, 8-15-1988) 
Sec. 56-2. - Traffic code controlling. 
    Except as specifically provided by law, the provisions of this chapter, including the adopted state traffic code, shall be controlling in the use of city streets, alleys, thoroughfares, parks, parkways or any other public rights-of-way or municipally owned land, by pedestrians and by vehicles of every kind whether self-propelled or otherwise and whether moving or at rest. 
(Code 2000, § 15-102) 
Sec. 56-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means any narrow highway ordinarily located in the interior portion of platted blocks and ordinarily used for service or delivery purposes at the rear of stores, dwellings, or buildings. 
    Ambulance means a motor vehicle constructed, reconstructed or arranged for the purpose of transporting ill, sick, or injured persons. 
    Bicycle means a device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels. 
    Bus means every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten passengers and used for the transportation of persons, and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Business district means the territory contiguous to, and including a highway if there are buildings within 600 feet of the highway in use for business or industrial purposes, including but not limited to hotels, banks, or office buildings, railroad stations, and public buildings which occupy at least 300 feet of frontage on one side or 300 feet collectively on both sides of the highway. 
    Center lane means any clearly marked center lane. If the center lane is not marked and no cars are parked on the roadway, then the center lane is equally distanced between the curbs or travelled portion of the roadway. In the event vehicles are parked on one side of the roadway only, then the center lane is equally distanced from the side of the parked vehicles toward the street and curb on the opposite roadway. If vehicles are parked on each side of the roadway, then the center lane is equally distanced from the edges of the parked vehicles. 
    Commercial vehicles means every vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Controlled access highway means every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
    Crosswalk means that part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the street measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway. The term "crosswalk" also means any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Double park means parking or stopping a vehicle on the roadway side of another vehicle already parked adjacent to the edge or curbing of the roadway. 
    Driver or operator means a person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Emergency means an unforeseeable occurrence of temporary duration causing or resulting in an abnormal increase in traffic volume, cessation or stoppage of traffic movement, or creation of conditions hazardous to normal traffic movement, including fire, storm, accident, riot, or spontaneous assembly of large numbers of pedestrians in such a manner as to impede the flow of traffic. 
    Emergency vehicle means vehicles of the fire and rescue department, police vehicles and ambulances. 
    Highway. See Street. 
    Intersection means: 
(1)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadway of two streets, which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets join at any other angle, may come in conflict; or 
(2)  Where a street includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided street by an intersecting street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting street also includes two roadways 30 feet or more apart, then every crossing of two roadways of such streets shall be regarded as separate intersections. 
    Laned roadway means a roadway which is divided into two or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Limit lines means boundaries of parking areas, loading zones and nontraffic areas and lines indicating the proper place for stopping where stops are required. 
    Limited access highway. See Controlled access highway. 
    Loading zone means a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or material. 
(1)  A freight curb loading zone is a loading zone for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of freight; 
(2)  A passenger curb loading zone is a loading zone for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled. 
    Motorcycle, motor scooter , and motor bicycle mean a motor vehicle, other than a tractor, having a seat or saddle for the use of the driver and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Official time. Whenever certain hours are named herein, they shall mean Central Standard Time, or Daylight Savings Time, as may be in current use in the city. 
    Official traffic control device means all signs, signals, markings, and devices not inconsistent with this chapter, placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning, or guiding traffic. 
    Park or parking means the standing of a vehicle whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers, providing such loading and unloading is in an authorized place. 
    Pedestrian means any person afoot. 
    Police officer means every officer of the municipal police department, or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic, or to make arrests for violation of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or roadway means a way or place in private ownership or leading to property in private ownership and used for vehicular traffic by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner. 
    Railroad means a carrier of persons or property upon cars other than streetcars operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train means a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
    Residence district means the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district. 
    Right-of-way means the right of one vehicle or pedestrian to proceed in a lawful manner in preference to another vehicle or pedestrian approaching under such circumstances of direction, speed and proximity as to give rise to danger of collision unless one grants precedence to the other. 
    Roadway means that portion of a street improved, designed, ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulders. In the event a street includes two or more separate roadways, the term "roadway," as used herein, shall refer to any such roadway, separately, but not to all such roadways, collectively. 
    Safety zone means the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times. 
    School zone means all streets or portions of streets immediately adjacent to a school, or school grounds where same is adjacent, and for a distance of 300 feet in each direction. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines or at lateral lines of the roadway and adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Stand or standing means any stopping of a vehicle whether occupied or not. 
    Stop or stopping, when prohibited, means any halting even momentarily of a vehicle whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic signal. 
    Stop, when required, means the complete cessation from movement. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is opened to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Through street or highway means a street, or boulevard or highway or portion thereof at the entrances to which: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic from intersecting streets or highways is required by law to come to a full stop before entering or crossing; and 
(2)  Stop signs are erected as provided in this part. 
    Traffic means pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances, either singularly or together, while using any highway or street for purpose of travel. 
    Traffic control devices or signals means any device legally authorized and used for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    U-turn means a turn by which a vehicle reverses its course of travel on the same street. 
    Urban district means the territory contiguous to and including any street which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry, or dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than 100 feet for a distance of a quarter mile or more. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is, or may be transported or drawn upon a highway or street, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 2000, § 15-103) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions, 47 O.S. § 1-101 et seq. 
Sec. 56-4. - Obedience to traffic code. 
(a)  It is an offense against the city for any person to do any act forbidden or to fail to perform any act required by this chapter. 
(b)  It is an offense against the city for the parent of any child or for the guardian of any ward to authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  It is an offense for any person to authorize or knowingly to permit any vehicle registered in his or her name to be driven or to stand or to be parked in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1401) 
State Law reference- Required obedience to traffic laws, 47 O.S. § 11-102. 
Sec. 56-5. - Applicability to pushcarts, riding animals, or driving animal-drawn vehicles. 
    Every person propelling any pushcart or riding an animal upon a roadway and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 2000, § 15-206) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 47 O.S. § 11-104. 
Secs. 56-6-56-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 56-29. - Enforcement of traffic laws; establishment of traffic control division. 
    It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department or any officers that are assigned by the chief of police to enforce all street traffic laws of this city and all the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city. Officers of the department shall make arrests for traffic violations, investigate accidents, and cooperate with other officers in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon the department by this chapter and any other traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Code 2000, § 15-201) 
Sec. 56-30. - Obedience to police and fire officials. 
    No person shall wilfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire and rescue department official. 
(Code 2000, § 15-204) 
State Law reference- Obedience to police, 47 O.S. § 11-103; eluding police officer, 21 O.S. § 540A. 
Sec. 56-31. - Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The city personnel, subject to any directions which the board of commissioners may give by motion or resolution, are empowered to adopt regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of this city and to make temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than 90 days. 
(b)  The city personnel may have traffic control devices tested under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Code 2000, § 15-205) 
Sec. 56-32. - Public officers and employees to obey traffic regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States Government, any state, county, city, or governmental unit or agency, as well as to other vehicles. It is unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter by state statute. This chapter shall not apply to the military forces of the United States and organizations of the National Guard when performing any military duty. 
(Code 2000, § 15-208) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, 47 O.S. § 11-106. 
Sec. 56-33. - Issuance of citation tags. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized and directed to supply police officers with citation tags in sets, each set consisting of an original and at least two duplicate copies, for the purpose of giving notice to persons violating any provision of this chapter. 
(b)  Notice may be given by delivering the tags to the violator or by affixing it to the vehicle involved in the violation. 
(c)  Each citation tag shall direct the violator to appear and to present such tag at a designated place on or before a date and hour specified thereon. Each tag shall bear the registration number of the vehicle. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to abridge the power of a police officer to arrest any violator and take him into custody. 
(e)  The city personnel may require that the police officers use citation tags furnished by the city and that such tags are serially numbered, and may regulate the use and handling of the citation tags. 
(Code 2000, § 15-220)
